Tra questi interventi rientrarono la creazione della via principale e la neoclassica piazza Garibaldi, progettata dall’architetto Giuseppe Valadier, ma realizzata solo nell’Ottocento dagli architetti Pietro Bracci e Antonio Sarti e dall'ingegnere Luigi Mollari. La chiesa del Santissimo Salvatore sorge proprio sul lato opposto del semicerchio della piazza. Essa presenta una pianta a croce latina, con monumentale facciata neoclassica. Internamente è organizzata su tre navate e conserva una Pietà modellata dal Canova.

The castle is a high, majestic medieval fort and the symbol of Itri that is built around a high-placed pentagonal tower with a small crenellated surrounding wall, a second square tower even more imposing than the first and a third large cylindrical tower, lower down and linked by a chemin de ronde. The building, probably begun in around 880 by the Duke of Gaeta, was completed in 1250 with the chemin de ronde and the addition of the living quarters. The large cylindrical tower, called the “Crocodile” (coccodrillo), was traditionally thought to have housed a crocodile to which was fed the bodies of those condemned to death. The complex also contained a fortalice, or small fort, with three small cylindrical towers used as rest stops for horses, servants and policemen. After the significant damages incurred during the second world war, the castle was restored and reopened to the public in 2007.

Detta anche Porta della Costa, è la principale delle quattro porte di accesso al paese. E’ formata da un varco con arco a tutto sesto posto ai piedi di una torre quadrangolare, inglobata in edifici moderni. Si basa lateralmente su grossi blocchi di pietra su cui sono poste delle iscrizioni latine, che testimoniano la consuetudine medievale di riutilizzare materiali di spoglio da edifici preesistenti. Sugli stipiti della porta sono scolpite a rilievo le figure di un serpente e di un cane che l’iscrizione in latino indica come custodi della città: custodes sumus Itri nostri savissimi voracissimi.

Built on an old pagan temple from the 11th century, the church is the oldest holy building in the city. It is characterized by its central bell tower, positioned directly above the main entrance. It has a square shape, articulated over four floors, decorated with plates in coloured majolica. The interior of the church is organized with three naves and contains a fresco from the 15th century of the "Vergine con il Bambino", a wooden statue of San Michele Arcangelo in the main altar and a choir supported by column-bearing lions.
poi - label - term: Church of San Michele Arcangelo - Itri

poi - description - value: Questo museo demoantropologico custodisce ed espone le fonti e i documenti sul brigantaggio in una maniera innovativa cercando di evidenziare l'orizzonte culturale nel quale essi acquistano leggibilità e parzialità, con l’obbiettivo di identificare nuovi percorsi critici ed interpretativi del fenomeno. L’allestimento si articola in tre sezioni. Nella prima dal titolo “Ragioni della Storia”, sono raccolti documenti e reperti che presentano le giustificazioni che per circa cento anni - dalla fine del XVIII secolo alla fine del secolo successivo - resero legittima la repressione dei briganti. Nella seconda, intitolata le “Ragioni del Mito”, si mette in luce una ben diversa interpretazione del fenomeno alimentata dai ceti non egemoni, da artisti cosmopoliti o dall’opinione pubblica nascente, secondo la quale il brigante impersona il ribelle e l’eroe tragico. Nell’ultima, dal titolo “Ragioni del Luogo”, al visitatore viene offerta un’ulteriore interpretazione del brigante alternativa alla storiografia ufficiale e relativa ai briganti del basso Lazio, rivendicando la lealtà da essi mostrata ad una cultura locale e loro terra

Antico insediamento preromano, acquistò importanza in epoca romana perché essendo collocato lungo la Via Appia costitutiva una stazione di posta (un passaggio obbligato) per i viaggiatori che da Roma si recavano verso sud.  Il nome del paese evoca questa sua iniziale funzione visto che probabilmente deriva dalla parola latina iter che significa “via, cammino”. Nel Medioevo il centro abitato si arroccò intorno al castello e l’intero borgo venne circondato da ben tre cinta murarie, ancor oggi parzialmente visibili. Solo nel XVI secolo, quando venne meno il pericolo di attacchi esterni, l’abitato si espanse anche lungo la via Appia (città bassa). Itri fecce parte inizialmente del ducato di Gaeta, dopo passo ai Dell’Aquila, signori di Fondi, in seguito ai Caetani e rimase sotto il dominio del Regno delle Due Sicilie fino al 1861.

The remains of the Forensic Basilica (Basilica Forense) are found on the eastern side of the ancient Foro Emiliano (Forum of Emiliano). The basilica was a public building used in Roman times as a venue for public meetings and for imparting justice. Its structures were identified thanks to a drawing by Baldassarre Peruzzi, who in the 16th century saw the remains of a rectangular building surrounded by a colonnade. During the 18th century these were incorporated into Palazzo della Bonificazione, still in existence today, and some parts are visible from the Salita dell’Annunziata road.

L’arco costituiva l’ingresso monumentale del foro emiliano, verso est. La struttura, costruita a cavallo della Via Appia, in origine aveva forma cubica con una grande arcata per lato. All’estremità occidentale del foro si trovava un arco simile, che nel medioevo è stato distrutto e sostituito da Palazzo Vinditti. Nello stesso periodo anche l’arco quadrifronte doveva essere stato inglobato in nuove strutture, che sono crollate a seguito di un bombardamento nel 1943.

La porta costituiva l’accesso sud-est del circuito murario che cingeva l’insediamento di epoca volsca e romana. Abbattuta nel 1831, si conserva solo la torre sinistra, pertinente alle integrazioni della cintura muraria realizzate nel V secolo d.C., trasformata poi in abitazione. La sua localizzazione è inoltre indicata da due leoni funerari di epoca romana, collocati davanti alla porta nel Medio Evo.

L’originario edificio in stile romanico-laziale risale alla metà dell’XI secolo, ma del suo impianto longitudinale restano soltanto parti dei muri perimetrali, gli archi della navata di sostegno alla cupola e il campanile, che presenta una decorazione policroma riconducibile alla scuola campana del XI-XII secolo. Il campanile, dal quale si poteva accedere alla chiesa, è composto da un basamento aperto, con al di sopra quattro livelli separati da una cornice. I primi due livelli presentano una tessitura muraria in pietrame irregolare, mentre al terzo livello mostra un’opera listata inclusa tra due cornici con mensole, con inserti di ciotole maiolicate ed elementi romboidali di pietra lavica. Tra le due cornici si aprono bifore con ghiere a sesto acuto, in laterizio, poste entro una cornice più ampia a duplice archetto a tutto sesto. L’ultimo piano, molto danneggiato, ha semplici monofore. La cripta della chiesa, distrutta completamente dai bombardamenti della seconda guerra mondiale, presentava una ricca decorazione ad affresco di cui sono stati staccati alcuni brani, ora conservati nella vicina chiesa di S. Angelo.
poi - label - term: Church of Santa Maria Maggiore - Itri

poi - description - value: il Convento di San Francesco, adibito sino a poco tempo fa ad ospedale civile tra 1874 e il 1994, si ritiene fondato proprio dal Santo di Assisi, nel XIII secolo. Del complesso originario si conserva buona parte dell’impianto generale, costruito secondo i canoni dell’architettura cistercense, nonostante le distruzioni subite nell’ultima guerra e le successive ricostruzioni. L’aspetto originale è ravvisabile nel piccolo campanile della chiesa, dalla caratteristica copertura conica. Anche la pianta della chiesa è rimasta sostanzialmente immutata, di tipo longitudinale. Sulla navata unica si affacciano sei cappelle laterali e un presbiterio rialzato con altare maggiore dedicato a S. Francesco. Nei pressi dell’altare è collocata una botola non più praticabile, che dava accesso a locali sotterranei in cui venivano sepolti i monaci. Le sistemazi ottocentesche del complesso hanno interessato anche il mulino, dove venne alloggiato il reparto di pediatria.
poi - label - term: Chiesa e convento di S. Francesco - Terracina

poi - description - value: The monastery (Convento dei Passionisti) was founded in 1574 by the Capuchin Friars who lived there until 1897. In 1910-11 it was used as a lazaret, or quarantine, following a cholera epidemic that raged through Itri. The Passionist Friars arrived in 1942, while restoration work was completed after the second world war. At right angles to the monastery is the church dedicated to the Madonna di Loreto, a building with a longitudinal plan whose facade, divided by four pilaster strips, is complete with a split tympanum. The church houses a painting by Sebastiano Conca (1676-1764) of the founder of the Passionists, S. Paolo della Croce.
poi - label - term: Monastery of the Passionisti and Church of Santa Maria di Loreto - Itri

poi - description - value: Palazzo Braschi was built in the second half of the 18th century as a papal residence.  It was built by incorporating older structures including the remains of the Church of Santa Maria in Posterula. Towards the end of the 18th century a new project to build a ramp (now Via Posterula) and remove a section of the town walls allowed the palazzo to be linked both to the so-called Città Alta (‘upper town’) and the Appian Way, and also to the new Borgo Pio in the Città Bassa (‘lower town’).

Il museo è stato fondato nel 1894 da Pio Capponi, di cui porta il nome. Esso è situato nel centro storico di Terracina, all’interno della duecentesca Torre Frumentaria. Esso conserva testimonianze provenienti dagli scavi della città e del territorio limitrofo, in particolare dal santuario romano di Monte Sant’Angelo. La collezione documenta la storia del territorio dalla prima presenza umana sin dal paleolitico superiore, periodo al quale sono riferiti resti di fauna fossile ed industria litica provenienti dal sito del "Riparo Salvini". L'epoca romana è la meglio rappresentata, con epigrafi, sarcofagi, ritratti di età tardo-repubblicana e imperiale e sculture a figura intera. Di recente l’allestimento si è arricchito dei reperti provenienti da scavi subacquei (oggetti navali, prodotti commerciali, anfore).
poi - label - term: Pio Capponi Civic Archaeological Museum - Terracina

poi - description - value: Sul lato sud della piazza si erge la Torre Frumentaria, detta anche dei Rosa, dal nome della famiglia che ne avrebbe commissionato la costruzione tra XII e XIII secolo. Essa presenta una base quadrangolare ed un alzato di circa 30m, costituendo un esempio notevole di architettura civile fortificata. Di particolare rilievo sono le due grandi porte ad arco acuto sul lato nord e l’originaria monofora, pure archiacuta, sul lato ovest. L’edificio, parzialmente distrutto dai bombardamenti dell’ultima guerra e successivamente restaurato, ospita oggi il Museo Civico, l’Ufficio Cultura e l’Archivio Storico Comunale.

The Foro Emiliano (Forum of Emiliano) represented the centre of civil and religious life in the Roman town. Along its northern side it was crossed by the Appian Way, paved in limestone slabs with a triumphal arch at both the east and west edges, of which only the east arch (quadrifrons arch) is preserved. On the sides of the forum stood the main public buildings including the Forensic Basilica (Basilica Forense) on the east side, the venue for public meetings and for imparting justice; on the north side was a colonnade that faced onto the Appian Way and was raised up three steps, with marble columns and paving. Behind this were discovered the remains of the theatre. On the west side stood a large temple from the period of the Roman Empire, whose high podium is preserved inside the cathedral. Next to this towards the north is a second, smaller temple identified as the ‘Capitolium of the Roman colony’ (329 BC). The forum retained its function as the town centre even throughout the Middle Ages, when several Roman buildings were despoiled to retrieve building material or incorporated into new buildings. This period saw the construction of the Cathedral (Duomo) of San Cesario, the Torre dei Templari (Templars’ Tower) and Palazzo Vinditti.

The ancient Volscian settlement of Anxur was conquered by the Romans in 406 BC and made a colony in 329 BC. Given the increased importance of the town in Roman policy, the Appian Way linking Rome to Capua was directed through it in around 312 BC. This represented an important, fast military and trade route and the oldest part of the town near the road was aggrandized during this period. Along the north side of the Foro Emiliano (Forum of Emiliano) is preserved a section of the Appian Way with its uniformly square limestone paving slabs and pavement showing the bases of the rods that separated the walkway from the forum area. The rainwater drainage system is still preserved under the pavement. An inscription on several paving stones attest that the paving of the forum was commissioned by Aulus Aemilianus (Emiliano in Italian), from whom the forum takes its name.

Nell’area dell’antico foro romano, sul lato settentrionale si trovava un porticato affacciato sulla via Appia. Esso era sopraelevato rispetto al piano stradale ed era raggiungibile mediante tre gradini. Presentava una pavimentazione e un colonnato in marmo, di cui rimangono le basi e alcune porzioni di colonne. Alle sue spalle sono stati rinvenuti i resti del teatro, di cui sono visibili l’ingresso (aditus) est, la cavea e parte della scena. Questo risale forse alla ristrutturazioneurbanistica di epoca sillana (del I sec. a.C.). Nel medioevo sul teatro erano cresciuti edifici con il medesimo orientamento curvilineo, i bombardamenti del 1943-44 ne hanno provocato il crollo portando alla luce le strutture di epoca romana

The cathedral was built during the early Middle Ages on the remains of the Great Temple (Tempio Maggiore) of the Foro Emiliano (Forum of Emiliano), whose remains can be seen incorporated into the north side of the cathedral. It was consecrated and dedicated to patron of the city S. Cesareo in 1074, whereas the bell tower and front portico date from restructuring work during the 12th-13th century. The portico was built with column shafts and Ionic capitals from Roman buildings and it presents paving in the Cosmatesque style (first half of the 13th century) depicting allegorical figures and mythological animals. The interior of the cathedral is organized with three naves subdivided by columns that have also been used previously, and it is paved in the Cosmatesque style with geometric designs formed by fragments of coloured marble and gilt tiles, as are the spiral column for the Paschal candle, and the pulpit. The vaulted, frescoed ceiling was built in the 18th century.

Palazzo Venditti is a 13th century Gothic building that was the first town hall. It faces onto the main square to the right of the cathedral, across the Appian Way, which it straddles with an ogival arch. It still features one of its original three-light windows.

The Capitolium is situated on the west side of the Foro Emiliano (Forum of Emiliano). According to some scholars it dates from the middle of the 1st century BC and should be identified as the temple dedicated to the Capitoline Triad (Giove, Giunone, Minerva). The small temple originally had a facade decorated with four Tuscan Doric columns and was equipped with three cellas, or interior chambers, in opus reticulatum of tuff and limestone, partially remaining, under which are preserved deposits (favissae) of votive objects.

The ancient Volscian settlement of Anxur was conquered by the Romans in 406 BC and made a colony in 329 BC. Given the increased importance of the town in Roman policy in around 312 BC, the ancient Volscian boundary walls were strengthened in polygonal masonry and equipped with gates known as Albina to the south east and Maggio (from Maior) facing north towards Rome. Little trace remains of these today. At the beginning of the 5th century a new network of walls was built that made use of the preceding layout as a base, of which large sections were left visible. Square towers that were built into the walls have mainly been preserved, and a long section of the chemin de rond which, having lost its original function was turned into a public path in 1786 and surrounded by housing, also remains all but intact. The ancient openings would have been reused in the medieval walls as well.

Alla fine del X secolo, con la crisi del papato e la crescita di potere delle famiglie locali, l’abitato di Terracina fu interessata dalla costruzione di case-torri per uso civile. Allo scopo di controllare politicamente la città e il suo territorio venne avviata l’edificazione di un imponente castello, forse ad opera dei Crescenzi. Il nome gli deriva dalla famiglia dei nobili romani che lo occupò tra XII-XIII secolo. E’ detto anche Rocca Traversa per la particolare forma trapezoidale del maschio, l’unica parte dell’edificio che è rimasta, insieme all’ala sud, dopo i massicci bombardamenti aerei del 1943-44.

Sul lato ovest del Foro Emiliano sorgeva un grande tempio di età imperiale, di cui non è nota la divinità tutelare. Questo fu inglobato nel duomo in epoca medievale, ma se ne conservano l’alto podio in opera quadrata, con le favissae trasformate in botteghe, e parte dei muri esterni della cella. Questi ultimi sono caratterizzati dalle originarie lastre marmoree di rivestimento, da grandi semicolonne scanalate e da un fregio scolpito decorato con girali d’acanto.

The Ausonian town of Tarracina rose up on the southern slopes of Mount Sant'Angelo (227m above sea level). It became a Volscian town called Anxur, and was later conquered by the Romans at the end of the 5th century BC. A transformation of the holy area in the 2nd century BC was followed by restructuring during the 1st century BC. This consisted of a boundary wall and military base to control the route of the Appian Way, and a large new temple on a scenic terrace with a portico to the rear. After the Roman era the sanctuary was destroyed and set on fire, and its remains were known during the Middle Ages as Palazzo di Teodorico (Theodoric’s Palace). It was here that a monastery dedicated to San Michele Arcangelo was established, from which the hill takes its present name. The area was finally abandoned at the end of the 16th century with the depopulation of the town of Terracina.

Porta Maggio, which faces north towards Rome, was the main access gate to the original Roman settlement, and took its name from the Latin maior (meaning larger). The gate was knocked down at the end of the 18th century leaving two imposing lateral towers with front walls that diverge outwards for defence purposes.

The church lies in the town centre and consists of the 17th century conversion of a previous medieval church dedicated to San Lorenzo, of which only the bell tower remains. The church has a single nave with side chapels, a lowered vault and an elliptical dome.

The building can be dated to the early decades of the 1st century BC and presents a facade in opus incertum with five large arches on pilasters, now sealed with a wall. An arched window is preserved on the west corner, reinforced by large rectangular blocks

The monumental gate of Porta Romana stands to the northwest of the city. Its structure utilizes the Volscian and Roman network of walls, and it also rests on an ancient tower with a polygonal masonry base, constructed in opus incertum in the 1st century BC. Creation of the gate is attributed to Pope Pio VI at the end of the 18th century as a response to initial and persistent security concerns for the pope and his court, which actually lodged in the town in the second half of the century. The original wooden doors that enabled the gate to be opened and closed with a doorway are still in situ, also preserved.

La chiesa del Purgatorio fu costruita entro il 1780 al posto dell'antica chiesa di San Nicola. Presenta pianta centrale ed una facciata con alto ordine unico di lesene, sormontato da un timpano mistilineo.

La Chiesa di San Domenico, che si impone per la sua austera semplicità, fu probabilmente eretta tra il XIII ed il XIV secolo, in una fase in cui  a Terracina si diffusero gli ordini mendicanti dei Domenicani e dei Francescani. L’edificazione dei due conventi suburbani seguì le linee architettoniche tipiche delle abbazie cistercensi. Nel tempo il complesso ha subito un lento processo di decadenza, fino alla soppressione nella meta del Seicento e l’abbandono. Nel primo Settecento iniziarono i primi interventi di recupero, con l’erezione del nuovo campanile a torre, la ristrutturazione del coro, delle cappelle laterali, la sacrestia e degli ambienti del convento. Nel 1778 il complesso monastico venne quindi riattivato e restituito ai domenicani che vi rimasero fino al 1873, quando, con gli espropri dei beni ecclesiastici e la soppressione degli ordini religiosi, dovettero di nuovo lasciare il monastero, che rimase per lunghi decenni successivi nell’abbandono e nel degrado. Fortemente danneggiato nel corso del secondo conflitto mondiale, è stato restaurato e oggi è proprietà del comune. La facciata conserva un rosone e un portale sormontato da un piccolo protiro.
poi - label - term: Church and Monastery of S. Domenico - Terracina

poi - description - value: La chiesa, nota anche come S. Maria della Basilica Nuova, sarebbe stata consacrata da papa Alessandro III nel 1163, allorché il pontefice ricoverò a Terracina durante il conflitto che lo opponeva a Federico I di Svevia, detto il Barbarossa. Nel Seicento la chiesa subì una trasformazione per volere del vescovo Cesare Ventimiglia (1615-1645).
poi - label - term: Chiesa della Madonna delle Grazie - Terracina

poi - description - value: Il paese di Suio, oggi frazione di Castelforte con il nome di Suio alto, era un comune autonomo sviluppato intorno al castello da cui eredita anche il nome. Il Castrum Suji, era sorto per il controllo della foce del Garigliano nel decimo secolo d.C. a difesa dalle incursioni dei corsari saraceni. Dopo la battaglia del Garigliano (915) è entrato a far parte del Ducato di Gaeta, governato dai Dogibile. Venne fortificato nel 1023, quando fu creata la Contea di Suio di proprietà del conte Ugo e nel 1078 venne acquisito dalla Signoria dell’abbazia di Montecassino. La fortificazione viene ampliata in più occasioni dagli abati Desiderio e Gerardo per garantire un miglior controllo delle proprietà del monastero di Montecassino. I castelli di Suio e di Castelforte erano collocati in posizione tale da costituire un privilegiato punto di guardia al fiume Garigliano, che all’epoca era la più importante via di comunicazione tra l’abbazia e il mar Tirreno. Nel 1140 Suio entrò nell'orbita normanna  insieme a Gaeta. Durante la Seconda Guerra Mondiale, trovandosi sulla Linea Gustav, il castello è rimasto in parte danneggiato.

The origins of the church date back many years, but the numerous alterations made to the building over the centuries have made it impossible either to ascertain a date for the start of its construction, or to define a univocal style for the entire architectural complex. The building was in fact formed by the union of a larger structure with an east entrance, and a chapel with a north entrance that constitutes the oldest part of the church. Found on the walls of this chapel were several frescos dating from the 15th century that have been recently restored and are currently displayed in a special area that possibly corresponds to the site where the original chapel had been built using the castle as its foundations in around the 10th century. The present structure is the result of the latest restoration and liturgical renewal completed in July 2004, during which the 18th century wooden figure of San Michele Arcangelo - also included in the restorations on this occasion - was relocated to a chapel above the high altar where it had been originally.
poi - label - term: Chiesa di S. Michele Arcangelo - Suio

poi - description - value: With its obvious medieval imprint, the small village of Castelforte stands on a hill surrounded by the Aurunci Mountains, 11km from the coast. Its origins date back to the 11th century, although according to some sources the settlement rose from the ruins of the pre-Roman town of Vescia. The original settlement consisted of a castle built to defend the plains below. From an early survey of the area of Castelforte that dates back to the Inventarium Cajetani, or Caetani Inventory of 1491, we know that the fiefdom passed through the hands of various powerful Roman families. Between the 12th–13th centuries it was the fiefdom of the Dell’Aquila and Caetani families, with strategic prominence for the control of commercial traffic through the Garigliano Valley. The most dramatic period the village has experienced was during the course of the second world war due to its position on the defensive line known as the Gustav Line, established by the Germans to halt the advance of the allies, which was subject to incessant bombardment and retaliation. These events led to the Gold Medal for Civil Valor being awarded to the town. Visitors can still relive the past through their imagination, from the town walls that continue to surround the historic centre, equipped with large circular towers, entrance gate and imposing square tower, and the lookout point which enabled communication with the other fortifications in the area. The village of Suio Alto still contains the ruins of the castle and Chapel of S. Maria in Pensulis.

In the period immediately following the second world war, in a rationalist reinterpretation of the design of the original 17th century church destroyed during the war, architect L. Bruzio created this modern temple with its longitudinal floor plan. Positioned above the level of the road, the church is reached by a double staircase and terrace podium. The external elevation of the facade, with flat coping, presents a split structure whose central part is characterized by three high blind arches in brick and a high single-light window set above the main door. The side sections feature a mullioned window with three lights and pillars in brick above a smaller doorway, and are enclosed at either edge by two pilaster strips also in brick. Attached to the church is a modern square bell tower. The church was named after two saints, brothers who were physicians employed to care for the people as demonstrated by the Latin inscription located on the architrave of the two side doorways. The interior consists of three naves divided by columns and no transept. The central nave has a barrel-vaulted roof, while the side naves have flattened dome vaults. Chapels lead off from these which contain paintings from the 18th and 19th centuries, while the chapel dedicated to the two patron saints hosts treasured wooden sculptures from the 1600s representing the two physicians.
poi - label - term: Church of Santi Cosma e Damiano - Castelforte

poi - description - value: Il nucleo medievale è circondato da mura con dieci torrioni circolari e dominato dalla mole della torre quadrata trecentesca, punto di avvistamento e di comunicazione con le altre fortificazioni dell’area come quella di Suio. Nonostante i danni subiti nel corso della seconda guerra mondiale queste strutture sono ancora ben riconoscibili

Already from the first Auruncan settlements there has been a link to the vast area of thermal waters along the Garigliano River, bursting with various springs that reach temperatures ranging from 0° to 60°C. Some of these springs with hyperthermal waters (39-63°C) of various concentrations of sulphur and bicarbonate-alkaline-earthy-calcic qualities, have been used for therapeutic and aesthetic purposes since Roman times, becoming a tourist destination in recent years with the construction of bathing establishments. Referred to by Plinio and Lucanoas as the Aquae Vescinae, they were very popular in particular during the period of the Roman Empire, attested by the porphyry bathing pool known as Vasca di Nerone (Nerone’s Bath), which you can still visit at the Terme Duratorre resort in the Sant'Antonio district. Ranked as the first in Italy and third in Europe for iodine content, the waters are also sold as bottled table water.

The rock Sanctuary of S. Michele Arcangelo was built by creating an artificial platform in the rock 12m long and 10m wide. Opposite the entrance is a niche on the end wall, also carved from the rock, which features a statue of the saint. The facade faces west and has a central doorway with a pointed arch and rose window above, flanked by two protruding lateral structures. On the arch of the door, next to the inscription "Angelorum Principi" are two dates, 830, the year of the founding of the old monastery, and August 5th 1895, the date of the inauguration of the new sanctuary created by engineer Silvio Forte of Trivio. As this area is rich in spring waters that percolate from the rock vault itself, ice-cold water also seeps from the walls inside the church and is collected in various stone basins placed outside, used to water livestock.
poi - label - term: Sanctuary of San Michele Arcangelo - Spigno Saturnia

poi - description - value: Il tratto di Appia Antica che sale lungo la Valle di S. Andrea, nei pressi delle gole al valico di Itri è stato recentemente sistemato a parco e permette di conoscere l’aspetto originale dell’antica strada romana, che collegava Roma a Capua rappresentando un’importante percorso militare e commerciale di rapido collegamento. La costruzione della strada risale al 312 a.C. circa, essa venne realizzata tagliando il fianco roccioso del monte e poggiandola su imponenti mura in opera poligonale, alte fino a 12m. Nel corso dei restauri è stata lasciata a vista la campionatura dei vari interventi succedutisi nella storia: a partire dal consolidamento al manto stradale, in poligoni di basalto vulcanico, commissionato da  Caracalla fino agli interventi di età medievale e moderna. Per esempio, al 1568 risale il restauro commissionato da Parafán de Ribera, vicerè di Napoli, e voluto da Filippo II di Spagna; al 1768 risalgono gli interventi voluti da Ferdinando IV di Borbone.
poi - label - term: 2600 Metres of the ancient Appian Way - Itri

poi - description - value: Conosciuto anche come Spigno Superiore, il Borgo sorge in posizione panoramica sul versante orientale del Monte Petrella e presenta una struttura urbanistica tipicamente medievale, che si sviluppa intorno al Castello. Di quest’ultimo sono rimasti solo i ruderi dell’alta torre quadrata e dell’antica cinta muraria, munita di torri. Durante la seconda Guerra Mondiale, Spigno fu quasi interamente distrutta dai bombardamenti dei tedeschi e dopo il conflitto fu deciso di costruire una Spigno Nuova nella pianura sottostante il borgo, per questo motivo ha ricevuto una medaglia d’argento al merito civile.
poi - label - term: Borgo di Spigno Vecchio - Spigno Saturnia

poi - description - value: At the beginning of the 20th century the 4m high cast iron statue of Cristo Redentore was put in place on the summit of Mount Altino, a little higher than the Sanctuary of S. Michele (1367m). It is one of 20 monuments installed on the peaks of the most representative Italian mountains in 1900 to celebrate the jubilee year and the start of a new century
poi - label - term: Statue of Cristo Redentore - Spigno Saturnia

poi - description - value: The Fort of Sant'Andrea stands on the remains of an ancient temple dedicated to Apollo. With high terracing (up to 14m) in polygonal masonry and cement, its interior contains 27 large vaulted cisterns dating from late antiquity. A chapel was built on top of the temple in honour of S. Andrea Apostolo. Over time the ruins of the temple were reused to fortify the pass that represented access to the Kingdom of Naples, and was the focus of great battles from the Middle Ages and throughout the modern period. The current appearance of the fort dates back to 1810 when, at the request of Joachim Murat, King of Naples, the temple was finally levelled, along with anything remaining from the ruins of the sanctuary, which still stood on the terracing.
poi - label - term: Forte di Sant’Andrea, su resti di villa romana - Itri

poi - description - value: La parte più alta di Spigno è dominata dai ruderi del Castello medievale, una fortezza in pietra, con alta torre quadrata e torrioni laterali edificata alla fine del X secolo su uno sperone di roccia a forma trapezoidale ad opera dei Normanni (XII sec.). Posseduto prima dei Dell’Aquila, successivamente divenne proprietà di diverse famiglie tra cui i Caetani, a partire dal 1363. Nel corso dei secoli, il Castello subì notevoli danneggiamenti. Nel 1690, della fortezza rimaneva in piedi soltanto l'alta torre quadrata, mentre erano in rovina gli altri edifici. Era distrutta anche la chiesa di San Lorenzo, sita all'interno del complesso, nella cui cripta si notano ancora oggi tracce di affreschi. Abolita la feudalità (1806), il Castello divenne proprietà privata e da allora le strutture murarie subirono un progressivo abbandono. Alla fine di gennaio del 1944, i Tedeschi, nel corso si un’operazione di guerra fecero saltare in aria l'alta torre, causando danni irreparabili anche alle restanti parti del complesso architettonico. Oggi si conservano due torrioni cilindrici, per lo più, nascosti dall’ingente vegetazione.

Lake Fondi is the largest coastal lake in Lazio. It is located in the municipalities of Fondi and Monte San Biagio. It is crescent-shaped with the tips turned towards the sea, and has an average depth of 9.1m, although is 30m deep in parts. It connects to the Tyrrhenian Sea a few kilometres away, along canals Canneto (2.3 km long) and Sant’Anastàsia (3.1 km long) and is fed freshwater from the Vetere, S. Magno, Marangio, S. Vito, Acqua Chiara and Catenaccio canals, which make its waters brackish. The outline of its edges are very jagged and covered in reed beds, which break off into the “ballene”, or floating islands formed by roots and reeds. Since 2006 the lake has been part of the Lake Fondi Natural Monument (Monumento Naturale del Lago di Fondi) set up by Lazio Region (Regione Lazio).
poi - label - term: Monumento naturale del Lago di Fondi

poi - description - value: L’aspetto attuale del Santuario, situata a 670 m, ha origini che risalgono all'anno 1000 e successive fasi costruttive: al 1491 risale la consacrazione dell’edificio, realizzato come ampliamento di una precedente fondazione dell’VIII secolo. Al 1820 si deve la ricostruzione del complesso cui parteciparono gli stessi fedeli, su progetto dell’architetto Silvestro De Donatis. La chiesa, ha pianta longitudinale a 3 navate, divise da pilastri cruciformi. La facciata presenta un pronao fortemente aggettante spartito all’interno da archi ogivali, che seguono il profilo delle volte a crociera. All’estremità superiore si trova un piccolo rosone, incorniciato da un doppio ordine di lesene, e il timpano. All’interno, varie cappelle si aprono nelle navate laterali, mentre la profonda abside ospita un altare in marmi policromi di stile barocco. Su di esso si conserva da secoli un dipinto di origine bizantina, raffigurante la Madonna con le braccia aperte in atto di supplica e con in grembo il bambino benedicente, attribuito secondo la leggenda a S. Luca Evangelista e sfuggito miracolosamente alla furia iconoclasta dell’VIII sec. d.C.
poi - label - term: Santuario della Madonna della Civita e Collezione di ex-voto - Itri

poi - description - value: Il santuario di Santa Maria del Piano fu eretto agli inizi del XII secolo sopra i resti di un tempio romano dedicato alla dea Concordia. L'edificio venne ristrutturato nel XV secolo, con l'aggiunta del caratteristico portico a quattro arcate (ultimato nel 1448). L'ìinterno ha una pianta a tre navate, di tipo basilicare, ed è decorato da opere d'arte risalenti per lo più al XV o al XVI secolo, tra cui spicca un trittico del pittore napoletano Giovanni Filippo Criscuolo. Dal presbiterio si accede alla cripta, con affreschi risalenti alla fine del XII secolo.
poi - label - term: Ausonia, The Church of Santa Maria del Piano
poi - location - address - value: Frosinone  via Orfanotrofio

poi - description - value: The monastery complex buildings are distributed along the slopes of Mount Arcano. These originally comprised the church, a curtis or agricultural court with working equipment, the cloister, dormitory and canteen for the monks. It is still possible to visit the upper Renaissance church with rectilinear presbytery marked by an arch in the shape of the coat of arms of the Olivetani. The lower church with frescoed apse was recently rediscovered. The bell tower is adorned by a 16th century spire. Near the source of the Ligola River you can still see the old Chapel of S. Paterno and the ample living quarters, oil mill and water mill with its aqueduct. The abbey was founded by S. Onorato (592 AD) at the simple hermitage of saints Paterno and Magno and prospered until the middle of the 11th century, when it was appropriated within the property of Montecassino. It had a brief respite when it passed to the Olivetani congregation and became the recipient of substantial donations from the Colonna family who succeeded the Caetani of Fondi. It began to decline towards the middle of the 17th century, concluding in its complete abandonment.

Il borgo è adagiato sul fianco del Monte Calvo (133 m) con un andamento semicircolare, come la poppa di una nave. Esso presenta una struttura a fuso con strade strette e tortuose, di cui quella principale, via Vittorio Emanuele, inizia da porta S. Rocco e conduce fino al castello Caetani. Al centro dell’abitato, che presenta ancora caratteristiche medievali, sorge il Duomo dedicato a S. Giovanni Battista. Qui si conservano il busto d’argento del patrono, S. Biagio, un trittico di Cristoforo Scacco (XVI sec.) con lo sposalizio di S. Caterina e alcune pregevoli tele del ‘700. Poco distante da essa si trova il Portico dello Scacco (1400 ca.), noto anche come Casa del Vescovo perché in esso vi morì il Vescovo di Fondi (†1537), Giacomo Pellegrino. Degna di nota è anche la chiesa di S. Rocco (ca. XII sec.), vicina all’omonima porta, in cui è conservata una statua del Santo oggetto di grande devozione.L’abitato di età longobarda (VII sec.) sarebbe sorto su resti di età romana di cui non rimangono tracce evidenti. Nel tardo medioevo fu feudo della famiglia Caetani, cui si deve la trasformazione del castello originario. Il paese fece parte del Regno di Napoli, rappresentando un punto di controllo strategico sull’Appia al confine con lo Stato Pontificio. All’indomani della proclamazione dello stato unitario (1861) il suo territorio fu interessato dal fenomeno del brigantaggio.

L’edificio ha una pianta trapezioidale con quattro torri angolari, al quale si lega la cinta di mura con le tre porte di S. Rocco, di S. Vito e del Castello, principali accessi all’abitato di Monte San Biagio. Oggi non è agevole identificarne l’impianto originario a causa delle numerose costruzioni successive che vi si sono addossate. Ancora riconoscibili sono una torre e parte del muro di cinta. Il nucleo originario del castello risalirebbe all’altomedioevo (ca. VII sec.) e sarebbe sorto su resti di epoca romana. Nel corso del ‘400 venne trasfromato e ampliato su commissione della famiglia dei Caetani.

Le prime attestazioni del Castello di Fratte risalgono all'XI secolo, anche se le strutture oggi visibili sono per lo più databili al Trecento. Anche se il circuito murario è in buona parte crollato, è ancora possibile ammirare il mastio e alcune torri laterali, di forma quadrangolare, dotate di feritoie e archibugiere.
poi - location - address - value: Frosinone  via San Michele

poi - description - value: The church has a longitudinal floorplan preceded by a narthex. Placed at the level of the apse is the bell tower (end of the 13th - beginning of the 14th century) on a square plan with octagonal superstructure supporting the spire. The doorway of the church is finished with pointed arches, thin lateral columns resting on column-bearing figures and an architrave with the coat of arms of the Caetani of Aragona. The interior consists of a large nave flanked by a smaller lateral nave divided into four bays articulated by pointed arches on pillars and covered by groin vaults. The main nave displays a ceiling with wooden roof trusses and culminates in a rectangular apse, where you will find an excellent wooden choir with Gothic accents. Until the beginning of the 19th century, access to the Caetani family funeral chapel (1489-1491) was from the left of the main altar, later desecrated and destroyed. The glass panels are the work of Giorgio Ascione (second half of the 20th century), a Franciscan monk from the Sacred Heart (Sacro Cuore di Gesù) of the Province of Naples, and depict the most important stages in the life of San Francesco. On the dividing wall between the two naves, at the height of the pilaster of the second arcade is a Roman ‘window style’ memorial stone (3rd - 4th century AD). The church is part of a monastery complex housing municipal offices since 1946, of which a cloister remains with a citrus grove. The S. Francesco complex was built by Onorato I Caetani (c.1363) on the location of an older and more modest place of worship, traditionally linked to the first Franciscan monks who arrived in Fondi. The monastery and church were restored by Count Onorato II Caetani, as mentioned by the inscription on the architrave of the entrance doorway of the church. Since 1466 the monumental complex belonged to the Order of Friars Minor Observants (Frati Minori Osservanti) of the Province of Naples who remained throughout various incidents, until 1881. Severely damaged in the course of the second world war, the complex was restored under the responsibility of a small religious community.

The Museum of Nature of the Circeo National Park was opened in June 1980 and is housed in a historic building, suitably restructured, dating back to 1960.The Museum includes very different environments in which important paleontological, archaeological and cultural evidences are kept. Spread over two floors, totalling 388 square meters of exhibition, the visitor route starts from the area dedicated to archaeology: from prehistoric times to geology, history and mythology. Casts of human remains show the evolution of the human species from the Australopithecus to the Homo sapiens. One section is devoted to illustrate, through a series of images and findings, the major European national parks and the Italian protected natural areas.Finally, some explanatory panels describe the various natural environments of the Park, represented by the island of Zannone, the Circeo promontory, the forest, coastal lakes and dunes with collections of botanical and entomological specimens, the sea and fishes. Of great interest is the presence of large aquariums with freshwater and saltwater with species typical of the park, and a tub of freshwater that reproduces the marshy environment. The Museum also has special ancillary services such as a library, a projection room, a film library service and guided tours in the Park.
poi - label - term: Museo Naturalistico Parco Nazionale del Circeo
poi - location - address - value: 04016 Lazio Lt 107 Via Carlo Alberto Via

poi - description - value: On the shores of Sabaudia Lake (Lago di Paola), within the Nature Reserve "Ruins of Circe," in the territory of the National Park of Circeo, there are the ruins of the  Villa of Domitian, a thermal-residential complex whose considerable size, approximately 46 hectares, make it one of the most important archaeological sites of southern Lazio.The Villa, dating back to the first century AD, includes, in addition to its spa facilities, the tanks, a gym, of which it’s still possible to see the basis and the channel that ran all around, a swimming pool and a small theatre. The internal garden housed a nymph adorned with statues and fountains; in the four-sided porch it’s still possible to admire fragments of polychrome frescoes and floors, some in pink herringbone pattern, very precious, of which there are few other examples.The site of the Villa was already occupied in the Late Republican age from other buildings, probably seaside villas, thus the design of the Domitian complex involved the transformation of most of these environments and facilities. A special feature of the villa is its complicated water system, consisting of a network of canals and reservoirs that ensured a good supply, having been built in a location away from any natural springs.The spa consists of a series of rooms arranged in "blocks", among which there are the frigidarium, the tiepidarium, the caldarium; the three exedras were a stage on the lake, with columns and windows: the Emperor and his guests lie on the triclinium could admire the striking view of the Circeo that still recalls the myths of Odysseus and the sorceress Circe. The wood leads to the tanks used for the supply of water; the largest one is called the tank of echo since voices echo and refract. It is 60 meters long, it consists of two parallel rectangular rooms that communicate thanks to sixteen arches, and could hold about 1,700 cubic metres of water coming through two aqueducts from the area of  Molella. Since the soil were sandy, they collected rainwater, which then entered through tunnels into the water main aqueduct, from there into the collection cistern and then into the tank of the echo. For centuries, the villa has been a quarry where to steal sculptures, artworks and other materials to be reused to build new monuments. The looting, devastation and total destruction of the Villa of Domitian was made by Cardinal Carlo Collicola, treasurer of the Apostolic Chamber since 1721.All the important artistic findings discovered in the Villa are currently on display in various museums, such as the Apollo of the Museum in Kassel and the Satyr of the Vatican Museums.
poi - location - address - value: 04016 Lazio Latina  Loc. Palazzo

poi - description - value: The Prince’s Palace, also called the Baronial Palace, is made up of a central rectangular body with cylindrical towers on three corners. The multi-stage constructed building encompasses the ancient Urbicus walls and would have originally formed one building with the nearby castle, united by an arch that formed the access to the city in the direction of Naples. Various architectural details, including a door and certain windows, display accents typical of Catalan architecture, due to the contribution of Catalan architect Matteo Forcimanya, who was commissioned to do the work in around 1466 by Onorato II Caetani. In the 16th century, the palace was the seat of the splendid court of Giulia Gonzaga, wife and then young widow of Vespasiano Colonna. During this period the residence earned the title “Little Athens” (Piccola Atene), for the cultural events that took place there. From 1861 to 1931 it was used as a prison and thanks to recent restorations, you can now see graffiti of drawings and writings by the prisoners in certain areas. Nowadays the building hosts the Civic Archaeological Museum, a conference space and hall for the town council.

The ruins of the building are visible a short distance from the castle. The complex stood just outside the ancient settlement, at what was originally the junction between the Decumanus Maximus (main Roman road) and an offshoot from the nearby Appian Way. Excavations have brought to light structures from various periods, including a calidarium and tepidarium, demonstrating the continual use of these from the Augustan Age to the 5th century. A mosaic dating from late antiquity with black and white pieces can still be seen in situ. Due to the fragmentary nature of the remains we are unable to understand whether the structure was an autonomous thermal complex or encompassed within a suburban villa, as the discovery of excellent marble finds and valuable furnishings and fittings would instead suggest.

La chiesa, in stile romanico, ha una pianta a croce latina. L’ingresso presenta un portale finemente lavorato, con pilastri poggiati su leoni stilofori e un architrave con bassorilievo raffigurante Gesù con gli apostoli S. Pietro e S. Paolo fra quattro santi. Nella lunetta mosaicata, opera del maestro locale Domenico Purificato (1970), è rappresentato S. Pietro nell’atto di ricevere le chiavi da Gesù. La figura del Santo troneggia sull’estremità superiore del portale dove, al centro di una edicola finemente decorata, è rappresentato in abiti pontificali nell’atto di benedire la città. Sul fianco destro della chiesa è posto il campanile in stile gotico (metà XII sec.).Lo spazio interno della chiesa è organizzato in tre navate mendiante due file di pilastri. All’inizio della navata sinistra si trova il battistero con mosaico cosmatesco e con un grande fonte battesimale in marmo. Esso si può far risalire al XII secolo, stessa epoca dell’ambone cosmatesco sito alla destra dell’altare e della cattedra di Clemente VII. L’abside centrale è dominata da una croce lignea dipinta, di stile bizantino, con i volti di S. Elena e di Costantino il Grande, alle estremità del braccio orizzontale della croce. In fondo alla navata si trova un altare barocco con la Madonna che allatta il Bambino, di autore ignoto e il Cristo deposto, del veneziano F. Trevisan. Nella navata di destra affaccia la Cappella della Croce, dove è situato il mausoleo di Cristoforo Caetani, morto all'assedio di Napoli contro gli Angioini nel 1441. Nella stessa cappella si trovano, l'uno di fronte all'altro, due grandi trittici della fine del XV secolo, quello dell’Annunciazione tra S. Onorato e S. Mauro, di Cristoforo Scacco (XV sec.), e quello della Maestà in trono tra S. Pietro e S. Paolo, di Antoniazzo Romano (XV sec.). La tradizione vuole che la chiesa sia stata fondata su un tempio di Giove da fedeli convertiti dai SS. Pietro e Paolo. L’ampliamento successivo si deve a S. Paolino che la trasformò nel duomo, dedicandola alla Vergine Maria. Al Conte di Fondi, Leone Caetani, si attribuisce la ricostruizione e la dedica a S. Pietro. Il duomo venne consacrato nel 12 dicembre 1638 dal Vescovo Maurizio Rogano, come si legge nell’epigrafe che sta all’esterno della facciata, alla sinistra del portale.

The museum is situated inside the Baronial Palace (Palazzo Baronale) and includes epigraphs, sculptures, memorial stones, votive offerings, terracotta and architectural fragments from the Roman era from Fondi and the surrounding area. Worth noting in particular are four figurative sculptures of people from the Verria gens, a milestone discovered along the Appian Way, a relief with funerary inscription and a marble sarcophagus. Also featured is a bas-relief of the Madonna e Bambino attributed to sculptor Domenico Cagini from the Church of the Madonna del Soccorso.

Il castello è costituito da un mastio a base quadrata, su cui s’imposta un torrione cilindrico con merlatura sostenuta da mensole,  per un’altezza totale di ca. 33 metri. Il castello sarebbe sorto in più fasi, di cui lo zoccolo intorno al XIII secolo e il torrione cilindrico nei primi anni del XIV secolo. Alla stessa epoca risalirebbero alcune parti del vicino Palazzo baronale. Il castello fu teatro del conclave scismatico del 1378, nel quale venne eletto l’antipapa Clemente VII e che valse alla città l'appellativo di "città di Satana".

The small church has a cruciform floorplan with a portico in front. Access to the church is from the portico and an entrance at the rear, probably the result of a modern restoration of the building. A blocked opening on the wall behind the altar would actually suggest that access was originally meant to be directly from the Appian Way. The interior is organized with a single nave and the walls display what are now faded traces of fresco decoration. Among these, the Vergine col Bambino stands out, of which remains an angel holding a candlestick, and the Crocefissione, on the wall of the sacristy. The latter was commissioned by Bishop Comparini, at the beginning of the 17th century. The precise date of the founding of the church is not known, but it is presumed to have been open for worship towards the end of the 14th century. Work on alterations commissioned by Count Onorato II Caetani seems to date to the 15th century, while in 1610 the church passed to the congregation of the Padri Gerolomini, who annexed it to a small monastery. Shortly after this, the unwholesome air from the nearby marshes convinced the priests to abandon the area.
poi - label - term: Church of the Madonna del Soccorso

poi - description - value: The church is in the Romanesque style with a cruciform floorplan. On the facade a high staircase leads to the three doorways, of which the central doorway displays finely detailed work with floral motifs and an architrave with the coats of arms of the Caetani family. The lunette above the doorway depicts the Vergine col Bambino between S. Caterina and Onorato II Caetani, who commissioned the church. To the side, the bell tower, complete with clock, is set further back in position compared to the facade. The interior of the church is organized in three naves by seven pillars. On the altar of the central nave you will find a painted wooden sculpture depicting the Madonna in Cielo (c.1513) by sculptor G.B. Amato (16th century) and an altar piece with the Dormizione di Maria and the Assunzione in Cielo (c.1534). The choir contains the tombstone of Bishop Nicola Pellegrino who performed the consecration of the church. On the left of the transept is a finely sculpted bas-relief ciborium (from 1491), while facing each other at the centre of the transept are twin Renaissance ambons. The church also houses a series of excellent paintings including the Trasfigurazione, the Disputa del Sacramento and a triptych of the Natività di Giovanni by Gaeta. The epigraph positioned at the top left edge of the central doorway informs us that the church was commissioned by Onorato II Caetani (1491), the first count of Fondi under Aragonese rule, and built on a prior place of worship possibly of the 12th century. Although the church had been open to worshippers for some time, it was only consecrated by Bishop Nicola Pellegrino on April 30th 1508.
poi - label - term: Collegiate Church of Santa Maria Assunta

poi - description - value: In origine Fondi fu una fiorente cittadina volsca e a seguito della conquista romana (334 a.C.), assunse la condizione di civitas sine suffragio (cittadinanza senza diritto di voto). Forse già da quella data la città venne dotata di una cinta muraria in opera poligonale, a delimitare un’area quadrata di ca. 400 m per lato. In epoca tardorepubblicana (fine II-inizi I sec. a.C.) la cinta venne rinforzata con aggiunte in opera incerta, con torri e porte, conservandosi praticamente inalterata nel corso del medioevo. Attualmente, il tratto meglio conservato è quello a nord-ovest dell’abitato, che doveva rappresentare il fianco più esposto della città antica, a protezione del quale erano state erette numerose torri. Sul fianco nord-est è osservabile l’unico accesso antico, la cosiddetta Porta Portella.

The Jewish quarter known as Giudea is found in the north east part of the historic centre of Fondi and is centred around Piazza Olmo Perino. This is a small square characterized by buildings with external staircases facing the direction where the synagogue originally stood. This would have been where the so-called House of Spirits (Casa degli Spiriti) now stands, which displays to the left of its doorway the symbol of the "mezuzah", or wooden frame used to hold the roll of prayers of welcome to the house.The district is home to a Jewish community that first settled centuries ago in the town. Documents from the 14th and 16th centuries certify as to the flourishing craft and commercial activities in the area, including the weaving and dyeing of linen, silk and hemp fabrics, and processing of leather and iron. Several workshops are still in existence today, and the Fondi Giudea is the only example of a ghetto in southern Lazio.
poi - label - term: Giudea Jewish Quarter or Olmo Perino

poi - description - value: The village is perched 647m high on a hill amid a ring of mountains close to the point where the Ausona and Aurunca mountain ranges meet. Inside the medieval town walls the urban fabric has a uniform and compact structure, with narrow lanes and steps, dominated by the Parish Church of San Michele Arcangelo. Situated at the highest point of the town, the church with its three naves contains excellent 16th century paintings and a painting of S. Michele Arcangelo by Antonio Sicurezza (1956). In Piazza del Municipio you can admire the Liberty Tree (Albero della Libertà), planted here to commemorate the French Revolution on the occasion of its first centenary. The village stands on the ruins of Apiola, a Latin city famous for bee keeping and honey production, from which it derived its name “Campus Mellis”. The fortified settlement is of Lombard origin (7th century) and was extended and refortified in the 11th century by the Benedictine Monastery of Montecassino to which it belonged in its function to control the road connections along the Liri Valley. Various churches were built by Ferdinando II of Bourbon, who personally inaugurated the work. The area was covered in dense woods in the 19th century, offering refuge to many outlaws.

The medieval walls including 12 towers surround the compact urban fabric of the village. Thanks to recent restorations, you can now follow the perimeter along an external footpath.   The walled section was built in the 11th century to defend the previous Lombard settlement (7th century), which at that time had become a vital checkpoint for the road connections along the Liri Valley.

Lenola represented the northernmost point of the Kingdom of Naples on the border with the Papal States. In the “Quercia del Monaco” district along State Highway (Strada Statale) 637 that links Fondi to Frosinone, you can admire a stone boundary marker that indicated the border of the kingdom. This is a small cylindrical stone bollard, on which is engraved the year it was put in place as well as the Bourbon fleur-de-lis on the side facing the kingdom, and the Papal crossed keys on the other side. This is one of the 686 boundary markers instated between 1846 and 1847 along the border between the two states that stretched for over 300km from the mouth of the Canneto Canal, on the Tyrrhenian coast between Fondi (Kingdom of Naples) and Terracina (Papal States), to the outlet of the Tronto River into the Adriatic Sea.
poi - label - term: Boundary marker between the Papal States and the Kingdom of Naples - Lenola

poi - description - value: The sanctuary, which overlooks the town of Lenola, was built at the beginning of the 17th century following the miraculous apparition of an effigy of the Vergine con Bambino. Construction began in 1607 based on the designs of architect Ambrini of Verona. In 1618 it was annexed to the diocesan seminary and the complex was inaugurated in 1628. For the occasion, two large cypress branches were fixed to the travertine cornice of the facade for decoration. These withstood bad weather and drought, and flourished for 372 years. The church has a Greek cross floorplan and single nave. Contained inside is an altar with excellent marble sculptures underneath an aedicula or shrine, and paintings of the Conversione di Saul and the Vergine con il Bambino (18th century).
poi - label - term: Santuario della Madonna del Colle - Lenola

poi - description - value: The medieval village stands on a hill at a height of 425m, surrounded on three sides by the Ausoni Mountains. Inside the medieval boundary walls the urban fabric presents a uniform and compact structure, with narrow lanes and steps that lead up to the Baronial Palace (Palazzo Baronale). Among the most interesting historic buildings are the noteworthy churches of S. Giovanni Evangelista, S. Maria Maggiore, S. Croce and Benigne Grazie. The origin of the town is relatively unknown. Several historians attribute its foundation to the Phoenicians or the Oenotrians who were navigators that arrived from the East and from the coast moved to the nearby mountains, where they built small settlements. The first indication of the fortified settlement dates to the 11th century, when it was bestowed by Littefredo, Duke of Fondi to the Abbey of Montecassino. Given its strategic position, the village played an important role throughout the Middle Ages, in particular for control of the drovers’ road that connected the Liri Valley with the Plain of Fondi. In the 19th century the village represented a strategic post along the border of the Kingdom of Naples and the Papal States. During the events that marked the unification of Italy it was also associated with brigandage.

The Baronial Palace (Palazzo Baronale) was built in the Early Middle Ages on the highest point of the village as the final protective line of defence for the settlement and to control the territory below. Today it is partly incorporated into modern buildings, although certain original sections are still recognizable including a four-floor tower. It was recently restored and converted into private accommodation.

Until its expansion in the 16th century the village was surrounded by medieval boundary walls with curtain-bearing towers, which continued towards the Baronial Palace (Palazzo Baronale). The main access route into the village was located where the gate called Porta S. Anna now stands, later replaced with the arch of the present Piazza Cavour in the 16th century. Of the defence towers, only the tower incorporated into the town council building remains intact.

La chiesa di S. Maria Maggiore è stata costruita verso i primi anni del XVI secolo quando, per il continuo incremento demografico, si rese insufficiente la vecchia chiesa parrocchiale di S. Giovanni Evangelista. Nel corso dei secoli ha subito notevoli trasformazioni, di cui le più importanti risalgono alla fine del ‘500. La pianta si presenta a croce greca, articolata su tre navate e con un nartece. Le due navate laterali, coperte con volte a crociera, terminano con cappelle decorate con stucchi. L’abside centrale, soprelevato rispetto al piano della navata, ospita un altare in marmi policromi dietro al quale si sviluppa un presbiterio, in cui si trova un coro ligneo (fine XVII sec.) di pregevole fattura, proveniente dal distrutto monastero di S. Magno di Fondi (nel 1807). Tra gli arredi sacri più importanti si conservano, nella navata, un quadro dedicato alla Madonna della Civita (XIX secolo) e uno della Vergine con le anime del Purgatorio. Annesso alla chiesa è il campanile, restaurato nel 1986, che si eleva su un fornice ad archi ogivali. Internamente esso ospita un pregevole fonte battesimale del XVII secolo.
poi - label - term: Church of Santa Maria Maggiore - Lenola

poi - description - value: La chiesa sorge a ridosso del Palazzo baronale e vi si accede da una piccola scalinata antistante la facciata. L’interno presenta una pianta longitudinale a navata unica, lungo le cui pareti laterali si trovano cinque archi a tutto sesto (3 a sinistra e 2 a destra). Sul lato destro si apre una piccola sagrestia dalla quale si accede al campanile. Tra gli arredi più importanti si conserva un affresco con la Madonna in trono con Bambino tra S. Rocco e S. Andrea (fine XV sec.) e una tela con la Madonna che porge il Bambino a S. Anna (XV sec.), posto su uno degli altari. Lungo il fianco destro della chiesa si eleva il campanile, articolato su due livelli e terminante con una cuspide ottagonale. La chiesa è documentata sin dal XIII secolo ed è stata parrocchia fino al 1574. Nel corso dei secoli ha subito notevoli trasformazioni che ne hanno alterato il primitivo impianto, mentre i recenti restauri hanno riportato alla luce alcuni paramenti originari.
poi - label - term: Church of San Giovanni Evangelista - Lenola

poi - description - value: This is a typical example of a small rural church, and is built on a longitudinal plan. On the facade, the limestone doorway features a lunette with a fresco of the Madonna col Bambino. Inside, above the only nave is a fresco of the Madonna col Bambino in Trono Mentre Domina il Demonio flanked by saints Girolamo and Michele Arcangelo. The central part dates from the 14th century and is certainly the work of a single artist, while the remaining elements are from later periods. Today the church is in a state of deterioration. It was built on the site of a pagan temple of peace constructed in Roman times along the consular road that linked the Appian Way to the Via Latina, passing near Lenola. It has been named after the Madonna delle Benigne Grazie since 912.

The origin and history of the Town Hall of Latina are deeply tied to the events that gave birth in 1932 to Littoria (changed into Latina in 1945), as part of the drainage of the Pontine Marshes decided by the Fascist regime.The town hall, which stands at the centre of the octagonal core on which the town was designed, was built by the Opera Nazionale Combattenti (National fighters corporation), who based on the design of the architect Oriolo Frezzotti.Conceived as the heart of political and administrative life of Littoria, it should have retrieved the values of magnitude and power that the regime wanted to convey, in order to arouse enthusiasm and participation in the population.From the balcony of Town Hall, on December 18th, 1932, Mussolini himself was to inaugurate the newly formed town. The building is flanked by the civic Tower, 32 metres high, on top of which there is the flagpole while the belfry houses a bell designed by the same architect Frezzotti.The building has two floors and a facade surrounded by a porch. Inside, there is a large garden at the centre of which there is a bronze statue of Daphne (1923), by E. Mayo, donated in 1933 by the Fascist Confederations of Employers and Workers.The ground floor has been occupied for years by the Gallery of Modern Art, opened in June 1936, while upstairs there were the municipal offices, the headquarters of the National Fascist Party and trade unions.During the post-Second World War period the symbols and decorations, especially in the main facade, reminiscent of the fascist era, were removed from the palace.
poi - location - address - value: 04100 Lazio Lt  Piazza del Popolo Piazza

poi - description - value: Le Grotte di Pastena, poste all'interno della catena dei Monti Ausoni, furono scoperte nel 1926 dal barone Carlo Franchetti e aperte alle visite turistiche già nell’anno successivo.Lo spettacolo naturale delle grotte è stato creato nei secoli da eventi geologici simili a quelli verificatisi nel Carso Friuliano, con forme di erosione e pianure legate ad antichi laghi carsici.Durante la seconda guerra mondiale, all'ingresso della grotta stazionava il quartier generale dell’esercito tedesco impegnato sul fronte di Cassino agli ordini del generale Kesselring, mentre le parti più interne offrirono rifugio alla popolazione locale.Le grotte sono attraversate dalle acque che, provenienti dal cosiddetto Fosso Maestro, escono sul versante opposto, finendo nella Valle del Sacco. La temperatura si attesta stabilmente intorno ai 14-15° e l’umidità relativa rimane sempre molto elevata, su valori intorno al 95-100%.Il percorso di visita, lungo quasi un chilometro, è composto da un ramo attivo inferiore, caratterizzato dal fiume sotterraneo e il lago blu, e da un ramo fossile superiore, dove le concrezioni calcistiche danno vita ad ambienti molto suggestivi. Oltre al sentiero turistico percorribile a piedi, ci sono alcune zone percorribili con battelli e accessibili solo a persone esperte.Lungo il percorso, si susseguono dieci sale i cui nomi richiamano la storia di questo affascinante luogo. Dal salone di ingresso si arriva, attraverso una galleria scavata nella roccia, alla Sala del lago blu, così chiamata dai primi esploratori per la presenza di un laghetto alimentato da una cascata alta circa 10 metri e da sorgenti sotterranee.Percorrendo la Galleria delle Meraviglie, abitata durante l’inverno da una popolosa colonia di pipistrelli, si approda alla Sala delle Colonne, la più antica e bella del complesso. L’età geologica di quest’area è testimoniata dal grande diametro delle colonne, generate dall’unione di una stalattite con una stalagmite. In questa sala si possono notare anche concrezioni “a fetta di prosciutto”, formatesi dal movimento delle acque carbonatiche su una parete inclinata e caratterizzate da diverse tonalità di colore dovute alle sostanze minerali disciolte nell’acqua.
poi - location - address - value: 03020 Lazio Fr  Pastena

poi - description - value: The Arch of Mark Antony, dating back to Roman times, is the most interesting testimony of what remains of the ancient Aquinum. Located to the left of the church of Santa Maria Liberata, today the arch is half-submerged in a water course and for centuries it has been used as sluice for a nearby paper mill.The approximate date of construction is 40 BC, but the reasons for building it and the dedication are uncertain. According to the legend, the arch was erected by Aquinas in one night to honour the consul Mark Antony, who passed through the town during his return trip to Rome from Casinum (now Cassino), where he was a guest in the villa of the Roman scholar, Marcus Terentius Varro. The incident would set off the irony of Cicero, who, in a passage of his "Philippicae ", defines the Aquinas as fools.The arch, made of large blocks of travertine laid on each other without any lime, is more than 6 metres wide and is located where the Roman town originally ended and the country road begun.The inner surface of the fornix has no decorations while the pillars are adorned on the sides by pairs of semi-columns ending with Corinthian capitals. The crowning, currently absent, is witnessed by a drawing by Giuliano da Sangallo.
poi - location - address - value: 03031 Lazio Fr  Via Latina via

poi - description - value: The Abbey of Montecassino, located 519 meters above sea level south-eastward of Mount Cairo, was founded by St. Benedict of Norcia on the site of an ancient tower and a temple dedicated to Apollo. Throughout its history, it has often been heavily damaged or destroyed by wars and natural disasters, but always rebuilt.Throughout the Middle Ages, the Abbey was a lively centre of culture, thanks to the enlightened leadership of its abbots, to the fame of its scriptoria who transcribed and preserved many works of antiquity, to the wealth of its books kept in libraries: from the first precious documents in the vernacular to the famous illuminated codex of Montecassino, ending with the precious and rare incunabula.The most illustrious of its abbots was perhaps Desiderio - the future Pope Victor III – who, at the end of the eleventh century, completely rebuilt the abbey and adorned the church with precious frescoes and mosaics, whose reflections can still be seen today in those the same Abbot commissioned in Sant'Angelo in Formis. From the Chronica Monasterii Casinensis we know that Desiderio spent considerable effort and funds for the reconstruction of the abbey church, accomplished in five years only, from 1066 to 1071, using stony materials coming from Rome and inviting Byzantine mosaic artists and various artisans. Of the paintings which decorated the church and the new rooms of the monastery, then rebuilt, few traces remain, such as the Stories Old and New Testaments in the foyer, of which the tituli written by the archbishop of Salerno Alfano are entirely kept.Destroyed once again by the violent earthquake of 1349, the Abbey went through another period of decline until it returned to being a great centre of culture and studies in the sixteenth century, crossroads of Europe, where the best minds of all countries arrived achieving great fame worldwide. In this period the Abbey lost its medieval character and acquired the style of the great sixteenth-century monastic architecture, thanks to renowned artists such as Bramante and Sangallo.Today, the abbey, however, is the result of another reconstruction undertaken after the entire complex was completely destroyed by the Allied bombing during the Second World War (February 15th, 1944). Thanks to the efforts of the Abbot Ildefonso Rea, who collected all the necessary documentation for a rebuilt true to the original of the sixteenth century, in 1945 the first stone was laid to give back to the community a piece of its high historical and cultural heritage.The architectural development of the Abbey is structured on different levels, with a grand staircase leading to the Church, rich in polychrome marbles and frescoes by Pietro Annigoni. The heart of the Abbey is the main altar, where the relics of St. Benedict and his sister St. Scholastica, found in 1950, are gathered.The facade of the church is a modern work of the engineer Breccia Fratadocchi and consists of three bronze doors that introduce into the basilica, the interior is composed of a nave and two side aisles and it’s decorated with stucco made on the basis of the original seventeenth-century design. The nave has a vault that in '600 was decorated with the paintings by Luca Giordano, now lost. Along the two aisles there are four chapels. To be noticed for its remarkable beauty is the black African marble portal through which visitors access in the rooms reserved to the monastic community. At the centre of the presbytery there is the main altar, a work of ‘600, keeping the bronze urn which holds the relics of the two saints: St. Benedict and St. Scholastica. The crypt is almost intact and it’s still possible to admire there a decoration in the mystic style typical of the German school of Beuron (1913).The Museum:The Abbey houses an interesting Museum established in 1980 to celebrate the fifteenth centenary of the birth of St. Benedict. Many are the relics and works of great quality and value visitors can admire in the Museum, such as: manuscripts, books, drawings and prints, ruins of the Basilica, Etruscan and Roman remains, wooden statuettes, Hellenistic, Etruscan and Italic vases, Benedictine paintings and sculptures, embroideries and laces.The Library:The abbey still retains its famous Library, although severely compromised by war destructions. Of the rich heritage, result of an immense cultural job, today over 1,000 codex, 40,000 scrolls and all the printed works with 250 incunabula have been preserved.The Library has been declared a national monument and it is included in the category of public libraries.
poi - location - address - value: 03043 Lazio Fr  Via Montecassino Via

poi - description - value: L'abbazia di Montecassino, adagiata sulle ultime pendici del Monte Cairo a quota 516 m.s.l.m., fu fondata intorno al 529 da san Benedetto. Per opera di grandi abati come Aligerno e Desiderio, Montecassino, nel X e nell'XI secolo, divenne uno dei più importanti centri culturali d'Europa, contribuendo in modo determinante alla conservazione della letteratura latina classica, e al tempo stesso conseguì una notevole importanza politica ed economica, che perdurò fino a tutto il XIII secolo.L'abbazia fu completamente rasa al suolo durante la seconda guerra mondiale (febbraio 1944) ma fu ricostruita nel dopoguerra cercando di rispettare il suo impianto architettonico originario.
poi - location - address - value: Frosinone  Montecassino

poi - description - value: The Church of Santa Maria della Libera is one of the most famous artistic expressions of all southern Lazio, built between 1000 and 1100 on the ruins of a Roman temple dedicated to Hercules the Liberator. The building, in pure Romanesque- Benedictine style, was commissioned by two women, Ottolina and Maria, belonging to the family of the Counts of Aquino.The church is located opposite the site of Aquinum, on top of a tall and monumental flight of steps. The façade is preceded by a grand porch with three arches supported by pillars. The last shelf preceding the entrance floor has been transformed into a short stretch of Roman road, with flagstones of the adjacent Via Latina; numerous boulders are scattered about the entrance floor, engraved with "tabulae lusoriae", a very popular game in the ancient Rome. The porch was added in the nineteenth century, as well as the rose window at the centre of the facade. The central portal has a lunette in Byzantine mosaic depicting the Madonna and Child flanked by two graves from which emerge Ottolina and Maria, founders of the Church.The bell tower, located on the left side of the facade, is integrated into the body of the church: the base is almost entirely made up of materials coming from ancient demolished buildings. The interior, composed of a nave and two side aisles separated by square pillars and three semicircular apses, is very austere. An imposing triumphal arch leads to the transept; in the centre there is the high altar, consisting of a Roman sarcophagus. On the left side of the church there is the triumphal arch of Mark Antony, with twin columns and Corinthian capitals.
poi - label - term: Chiesa di Santa Maria della Libera
poi - location - address - value: 03031 Lazio Fr  Via Madonna della Libera

poi - description - value: Il Foro di Traiano fu inaugurato nel 112 d.C. e la sua costruzione, finanziata con il bottino ricavato dalla conquista della Dacia, è attribuita al famoso architetto Apollodoro di Damasco. Per la realizzazione dell’imponente piazza verso N fu necessario effettuare il taglio della sella che univa il Campidoglio al Quirinale. Il complesso era costituito da un’enorme piazza porticata, pavimentata con lastre di marmo lunense, con la statua dell’imperatore a cavallo, l’Equus Traiani posta in posizione enfatica. A N la piazza era chiusa dalla Basilica Ulpia, alle spalle della quale si ergevano gli edifici delle biblioteche con la Colonna Traiana nel centro. I lati lunghi erano delimitati da due corridoi porticati con colonne corinzie in pavonazzetto dietro i quali si apriva un ampio emiciclo. La trabeazione dei portici era composta da un alto attico sul quale erano statue colossali di Daci prigionieri alternate a clipei con personaggi famosi. Alla luce di scavi recenti, il lato meridionale della piazza è apparso articolato in un prospetto colonnato mistilineo, con un tratto rettilineo centrale e due obliqui laterali. Dietro questo fronte era una corte porticata su tre lati, abbellita da una ricchissima decorazione marmorea pavimentale e parietale. Sul lato opposto era la Basilica Ulpia, raggiungibile tramite 5 gradini dal piano del Foro. Il grande edificio era suddiviso in 5 navate da file di colonne corinzie con fusti di granito grigio ed era provvisto di tre ingressi, corrispondenti all’esterno a tre avancorpi. Sull’alto attico erano ancora statue colossali di Daci alternati a lastre con rilievi di cataste di armi. L’interno della basilica, riccamente pavimentato in marmi policromi, terminava sui lati corti con due emicicli. Dalla piazza del Foro, proprio per la presenza della basilica, alta 40 m, era impossibile vedere la Colonna Traiana posta in un cortile stretto tra le due Biblioteche. Queste ultime erano costituite da edifici identici con due ordini architettonici sovrapposti inquadranti file di nicchie, tradizionalmente interpretati come armadi per i volumina.
