La fascia iscritta unisce in un unico complesso diversi corpi di fabbrica, tra i quali è possibile distinguere il palazzetto eretto ex-novo dal Manili, posto all'angolo con Piazza Costaguti, che si affiancò alla vecchia casa dei Manili e ad un'altro edificio, sicuramente preesistente, costruito in cortina laterizia con finestre a croce guelfa. La lunga iscrizione, che riporta sia il nome del finanziatore dell'edificio sia l'anno dei lavori (2221 dalla fondazione di Roma), e la pratica di inglobare nella muratura della facciata numerosi frammenti di sculture classiche, rispecchiano lo spirito dell'epoca, animata dal desiderio di recuperare lo splendore dell'antica civiltà romana. E’ inoltre inciso più volte sulle finestre verso Piazza Costaguti, il motto HAVE ROMA, mentre sulle porte poste al pianterreno è ripetuto in forme diverse, in caratteri greci e latini, il nome del fondatore, Lorenzo Manili.  Proseguendo lungo la via, ai civici 8 e 13 si incontrano gli antichi palazzi che appartennero ai Fabi di Pescaria, antica famiglia che vantava di discendere dalla omonima famiglia romana. Gli edifici, in laterizi, furono costruiti nei secoli XV-XVI. A tre piani, terminano in alto con una loggia oggi tamponata e presentano entrambi un bel portone incorniciato da un arco bugnato.Poco oltre, in un'area pesantemente interessata dalle demolizioni degli anni '20 del novecento tesi ad isolare i resti del portico d'Ottavia ed il teatro di Marcello, sorge  il complesso edilizio che oggi ospita la sede della Sovraintendenza Comunale di Roma: l'edifico, risultato dell'accorpamento di diversi corpi di fabbrica le cui prime fasi sembrano risalire al IX secolo, nel XIV secolo divenne sede dei Vallati, una delle più importanti famiglie del rione Sant'Angelo.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma 1-2 Via Del Portico d'Ottavia Via

poi - description - value: The church was erected on a previous building between 1662 and 1667 by Carlo Rainaldi on the commission of Pope Alessandro VII (Fabio Chigi, 1655-1667) as a votive offering to the Virgin for having freed the city from the plague in 1656. The sacred image of the Madonna preserved in the nearby church of Santa Maria in Portico, whose intercession is credited with wiping out the pestilence, was transferred together with the titular cardinalate to the new building, which thereafter adopted the extended name of Santa Maria in Portico in Campitelli, while the old church of Santa Maria in Portico was entitled ‘a Santa Galla’. The façade, in two orders divided by bands of columns and separated by a high cornice, is crowned with a triangular tympanum. The central sector is displayed in both orders by means of small shrines: in the lower order, the columns support a triangular tympanum which invades the space of the upper order. An effect of great momentum is achieved by the ensemble of high plinths on which the columns of both orders soar upwards. The interior has a succession of two different layouts which enliven the overall longitudinal development.  The first stretch is in the form of a Greek cross and is followed by a quadrangular core with cupola and apse.  On the high altar, inside a majestic tabernacle designed by Carlo Rainaldi, an icon is preserved of Santa Maria in Portico Campitelli, a foil and enamel work of the XI century. In the church, amongst others, works are preserved by Luca Giordano (Sant'Anna, San Gioacchino e Maria) and Baciccia (Birth of the Baptist).
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma 9 Piazza Campitelli Piazza

poi - description - value: La chiesa fu eretta, per conto dell’Arciconfraternita dei Falegnami, tra il 1597 ed il 1663 prendendo il posto di un precedente edificio di culto intitolato a San Pietro, sorto sulle strutture del Carcere Mamertino (l’antica prigione di Stato romana nella quale, secondo la tradizione, l’apostolo era stato tenuto prigioniero prima del martirio). Il nuovo edificio, alla cui realizzazione si avvicendarono diversi architetti, subì due importanti rimaneggiamenti, il primo alla fine dell’800, quando fu costruita l’abside semicircolare in sostituzione della più antica quadrangolare e il secondo nel 1932, quando, con la costruzione della Via dell’Impero, la chiesa venne isolata dal tessuto edilizio circostante e il livello stradale antistante venne abbassato per consentire l’accesso diretto, tramite un portico, al sottostante Carcer. Questo monumento, a sua volta, utilizza le strutture di un antico bacino, il Tullianum, nel quale si raccoglievano le acque della sorgiva ancora oggi presente a livello del piano di calpestio. Secondo la tradizione della prigionia di San Pietro, la sorgente venne fatta scaturire dall'Apostolo dalla viva roccia per battezzare, dopo la conversione, i suoi stessi carcerieri e quarantasette altri prigionieri: ancora oggi i devoti scendono nel Tullianum per bagnarsi alle acque della sorgiva e per accostarsi alla colonna dove sarebbe stato incatenato l'Apostolo Pietro.
poi - label - term: Tullianum e San Giuseppe dei Falegnami
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma 1 Clivo Argentario Via

poi - description - value: The construction of the Forum, also known as Transitorium, was initiated by the emperor Domitian and completed by his successor Nerva, who inaugurated it in 97 A.D.. The square occupied a restricted space due to the other Forum squares, crossed in the Republican era by the roadway of the Argiletum connecting the Roman Forum and the Subura. In order to obviate the lack of space, the Forum, in an elongated rectangular shape, was left without porticos, replaced on the long sides by a colonnade jutting from the walls. Following a change of design in the construction phase, the temple dedicated to Minerva was moved from the short, western side to the eastern side, where the foundations, which survived the latest demolitions at the beginning of the XVII century, remain visible. The temple, reconstructed on the basis of drawings from the Renaissance era, appears to be of the high podium type, with six columns at the front and three on the sides. Two arches opened in the seven buildings that enclosed the square on this side, with a trapezoidal space acting a vestibule; behind this was an exedra with porticos in the form of a horseshoe, known from the sources of late antiquity as Porticus Absidata. In the southern sector of the square (the central part is still buried under Via dei Fori Imperiali) is the so-called Colonnacce, two of the 50 grooved Corinthian columns in Pavonazzetto marble next to the long sides of the Forum. The trabeation preserves a sculptured frieze with scenes of spinning and weaving, recalling the myth of Minerva and Aracne; the attic would have had a series of panels with depictions of the people subjugated by Rome. The visible remains of a double arched lintel of blocks of tuff belonged to the top of the Cloaca Maxima, the vast sewage system dating back to the royal epoch.In the high Middle Ages, the square was once again crossed by a cobbled road along which, between the IX and XI centuries, residential buildings were constructed. After a period of neglect and the use of the ancient monuments as a stone quarry, the area, known by sources in the XV century as Fundicus Macellorum de Archanoè, assumed a new commercial role with the presence of numerous shops for the sale of meat.
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma  Via dei Fori Imperiali Via

poi - description - value: The villa, which preserves its Renaissance appearance, was built by Giulio Romano from 1518 on a commission from the Tuscan, Baldassarre Turini da Pescai, a Papal datary (dispenser of benefices) at the court of Leone X (Giovanni de’ Medici, 1513-1521) and executor of Raphael’s will. Raphael’s pupil followed the model of the Medici villas. The palace was based on a square plan, repeated in the interiors. The façade developed in two orders, Doric and Ionic, with a basement leading via a double ramp stairway to a monumental first floor. At the centre lay a rounded portal between two columns in peperino. On the opposite side was the loggia with Serlian motifs and a covered attic. A terraced garden surrounded the building. The overall design was influenced by the study of a plan from ancient Rome, begun in Raphael’s workshop and documented in a letter to Leone X. The interior decoration, coordinated by Giulio Romano with frescos by Polidoro da Caravaggio, celebrated the pontificate of the Medici Pope as the beginning of a new era for the city. Sold to the Lante in 1551, it was then acquired by the Borghese in 1817 who commissioned Luigi Canina to carry out restoration works. Since 1950, it has housed the Istitutum Romanum Finlandiae.
poi - location - address - value: 00165 Lazio Roma 10 Passeggiata del Gianicolo Via

poi - description - value: On July 14th, 1555, Paolo IV (Giampietro Carafa, 1555-1559), with the bull Cum nimis absurdum, established the Rome Ghetto in the Sant’Angelo district where Jews were obliged to reside.  The sector, separated from the rest of the city by a wall with three doors locked at sunset, occupied a hectare of the low-lying area on the left bank of the Tiber, under constant threat of floods.  The main entrance was in Piazza Giudea (no longer in existence), divided by the wall into two parts. In 1585, the area of the Ghetto was expanded to three hectares under Sisto V (Felice Peretti, 1585-1590) between the Tiber and the present Via del Portico d’Ottavia, later further extended in 1825 with the addition of a segment to Piazza Mattei under Leone XII (Annibale Sermattei, 1823-1829). During the first Roman Republic, the Tree of Liberty was raised in Piazza delle Scole following the opening of the Ghetto in 1798, which lasted only until 1815.  In 1848, Pio IX order the wall to be knocked down but, notwithstanding the brief opening during the Roman Republic, segregation only ended with the taking of Rome in 1870.The main road (and the most ancient) was Via Rua, parallel to the current Via del Portico d’Ottavia. Here, in the sector most protected from floods, the wealthiest families lived and the leading shops were established. The lively and characteristic streets of the Ghetto inspired some of the best watercolours in the series Roma Sparita by Ettore Roesler Franz between 1881 and 1887. At the site of the present Piazza delle Cinque Scole, the Jewish schools that had given the square its name were knocked down under the Regulatory Plan of 1888 which upgraded part of the Ghetto.  On this occasion, the Tempio Maggiore was constructed, completed in 1904.The Ghetto was the scene of the dramatic round-up of October 16th, 1943 with the deportation to Auschwitz of 1022 Jews, of whom only 17 returned.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via del Portico d’Ottavia Via

poi - description - value: Realizzata in un anno, tra il 1931 ed il 1932, per collegare Piazza Venezia con il Colosseo, Via dei Fori Imperiali venne inaugurata con il nome di Via dell’Impero il 28 ottobre del 1932. Per i velocissimi tempi di attuazione (collegati alle celebrazioni per i decennali della Marcia su Roma), l’apertura del lungo rettilineo, destinato a celebrare la grandezza della “Romanità” e del nuovo impero, venne effettuata senza un programma prestabilito e, soprattutto, al di fuori delle regole fissate dal piano regolatore del 1931, che prevedeva per questo settore interventi meno distruttivi. Nel tratto iniziale del tracciato, verso Piazza Venezia, venne completamente demolito il Quartiere Alessandrino (quartiere di origine medievale sorto sulle rovine dei Fori Imperiali e rimodellato alla fine del XVI secolo). Ai lati della strada, che occupa lo spazio centrale dei fori, furono sistemate strade secondarie con giardini e terrazze, in gran parte ancora esistenti, che affacciano sui settori più esterni degli antichi monumenti. Nel tratto successivo, per completare il rettilineo verso il Colosseo fu necessario procedere al totale sbancamento della Velia, la collina che separava l’area dei fori dalla valle del Colosseo. Con questa operazione la Basilica di Massenzio ed il Tempio di Venere e Roma, originariamente addossati alla collina, vennero isolati dal loro contesto orografico. In corrispondenza dello sbancamento vennero erette quinte in cortina laterizia su progetto di Antonio Muñoz: sul lato nord del viale fu sistemato un terrazzamento di sostegno del giardino di Palazzo Rivaldi; sul lato opposto fu eretto un alto muraglione su cui vennero affisse quattro tavole geografiche marmoree raffiguranti l’espansione di Roma dalle origini al regno di Traiano.
poi - label - term: Via dell’Impero, oggi Via dei Fori Imperiali
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via dei Fori Imperiali Via

poi - description - value: Per la sua posizione dominante e isolata il Campidoglio costituì fin dalle origini l’acropoli naturale della città. La sommità si articolava in due diverse cime ancora distinguibili nell’orografia moderna: l’Arx (la cima più alta, dove ora è la chiesa di Santa Maria in Aracoeli) e il Capitolium (corrispondente all’area di via del Tempio di Giove) separate da un avvallamento centrale (l’Asylum, ovvero l’attuale Piazza del Campidoglio) . Già abitato nell’età del Bronzo (XIV-XIII secolo a.C.) il colle divenne sede di grandi monumenti fin dalla fine dell’età regia e soprattutto in età repubblicana. Tra questi, il tempio di Giove Capitolino (dedicato alla triade Giove, Giunone e Minerva), il tempio di Giunone Moneta, il tempio di Veiove e un Auguraculum (spazio sacro per trarre auspici dal volo degli uccelli) insieme ad altri santuari e monumenti onorari. Alla fine dell’età repubblicana fu eretto sul lato verso il Foro Romano il Tabularium, sede dell’archivio di Stato. Su questo stesso versante erano inoltre localizzate le principali via di accesso al colle (il Clivo Capitolino e le Scalae Gemoniae). La sommità del Capitolium era raggiungibile anche dal lato opposto tramite una gradinata (i Centum gradus, verso il Teatro di Marcello). Fino alla piena età medievale il Campidoglio mantenne prevalentemente il suo carattere di rocca accessibile solo dal Foro e il suo versante nord-occidentale rimase per lungo tempo ai margini dell’abitato, lambito unicamente dal grande mercato sviluppatosi nell’area dell’attuale Piazza Venezia. Nel corso del XII secolo con l’insediamento della sede del Senato comunale e, successivamente, con la costruzione della chiesa di Santa Maria in Aracoeli, il Campidoglio divenne parte integrante dell’abitato e luogo simbolico dell’autorità cittadina e per questo si privilegiarono i collegamenti con l’area più densamente abitata del Campo Marzio a discapito degli accessi dall’antico Foro romano, detto Campo Vaccino. Tra il 1535 e il 1539 Paolo III (Alessandro Farnese 1534-1549) volle qui costruire la propria residenza estiva nella torre collegata al palazzo Venezia oggi demolita. La sistemazione michelangiolesca della piazza del Campidoglio sancì in forma monumentale il cambiamento del fronte della collina, tappa importante nella cerimonia papale del possesso nella quale il papa neo eletto attraversava la città, da San Pietro a San Giovanni in Laterano. A partire dal XV secolo il colle capitolino ospitò  nel palazzo dei Conservatori  la più antica sede museale al mondo. Un ultimo grande intervento di carattere urbanistico, operato sul colle per la costruzione del Monumento al Milite Ignoto, portò alla totale distruzione del quartiere medievale che occupava le sue pendici settentrionali alla fine del XIX secolo.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Piazza del Campidoglio Piazza

poi - description - value: The powerful Riario family, who were related to Sisto IV (Francesco della Rovere, 1471-1484), built the early nucleus of the palace in the XV century. The original building, on two floors, was constructed to a horseshoe plan with two wings protruding from the rear which bordered the courtyard, which opened onto the garden. Two avenues with statues, fountains and labyrinths led up the slopes of the Janiculum to the summit.  The palace was modified when it became the residence of Queen Cristina of Sweden between 1669 and 1689, and the circle that formed the Accademia dell'Arcadia held meetings there.  In 1736, it was bought by the Corsini, the family of Pope Clemente XII (Lorenzo Corsini, 1730-1740), who commissioned the Florentine architect, Ferdinando Fuga to completely renovate the palace and its gardens to make the residency worthy of its new status. Constructed between 1736 and 1770, the palace was one of the most important examples of the architecture of eighteenth century Rome.  Fuga incorporated the existing building with the long main façade on Via della Lungara, where he increased the original partition and opened up the majestic triple-arched portal, surmounted by a balcony supported by corbels and three windows with the coat-of-arms of the Corsini.  On the first floor are windows with rounded tympanum and characteristic conch shell embellishments. The portal leads to the majestic entrance hall and then to the garden, ending at the botanical garden established in 1883. The rear facade duplicated the layout of protruding wings of the sixteenth century building, joined by courtyards with porticos, Here lay the garden that exploited the slopes of the Janiculum with labyrinths, cascading fountains with statues and niches bearing the rose emblem of the Riario. Originally, the garden reached the summit of the hill where the Renaissance Lodge of the Riario stood, demolished to make way for the monument to Garibaldi.The seat of the embassy of the Directory of revolutionary France, it hosted Giuseppe Bonaparte and General Duphot, killed in the tumult between the palace and the Porta Settimina, the pretext for the occupation by Berthier and the expulsion of Pope Pio VI (Giovannagelo Braschi, 1775-1799). Sold in 1883 to the Italian State, today it houses the National Gallery of Ancient Art and the headquarters of the Accademia dei Lincei.
poi - location - address - value: 00165 Lazio Roma 10 Via della Lungara via

poi - description - value: Ancora oggi Roma città aperta è considerato il vero e proprio atto di nascita del Neorealismo Cinematografico Italiano, soprattutto per il rapporto diverso che la pellicola di Rossellini instaurò con l’attualità. Come gli altri capolavori neorealisti che seguirono, Roma città aperta mise in discussione la funzione del cinema come strumento di evasione e puntò piuttosto a raccontare la vita che accade sotto i nostri occhi, nel tentativo di scoprire una Italia inedita, fatta di paesaggi e situazioni che non erano stati raccontati dal cinema dei telefoni bianchi dell'epoca fascista.Alla fine della guerra la maggior parte degli studi era andata distrutta e la strada divenne il set improvvisato di molti film. In tale situazione precaria, ciò che ne guadagnò fu la libertà espressiva dei registi. Un esempio in tal senso è dato dalla sequenza dell'uccisione di Pina (Anna Magnani), in Roma città aperta (1945). Si tratta di uno di quei momenti in cui il cinema diventa leggenda, non solo per la carica emotiva delle immagini, ma anche perché l'uscita di scena a metà film della protagonista venne considerato un atto di coraggio da parte del regista e un fatto assolutamente inedito per il pubblico. La scena fu girata al quartiere Pigneto, in via Montecuccoli 17, una traversa di via Prenestina. Mentre una camionetta della Gestapo porta via il suo uomo, Pina si divincola dalle guardie tedesche e si lancia in strada nel disperato tentativo di ribellarsi all'arresto dell'uomo. Ma in quel momento una scarica di fucili raggiunge Pina, la quale si accascia a terra senza vita, sotto gli occhi del figlioletto Marcello.

The Torre dei Conti, also known as Turris Maior, was one of the highest in medieval Rome.Its substantial base stands at the north the current Largo Corrado Ricchi, constructed in 1932 on the occasion of the opening of the Via dei Fori Imperiali. The monument, currently enclosed by adjacent buildings, originally formed part of a fortified perimeter owned by the Conti family. Today, only the basement, 29 metres high, remains. The rest of the structure, which originally must have exceeded a height of 50-60 metres, collapsed during the violent earthquakes that devastated the city in the XIV and XVII centuries. The tower was erected on the area of the Forum Pacis of Nerva, commissioned by Pope Innocenzo III (Lotario dei Conti di Segni, 1198-1216). The building was restored several times during the XIII century following damage by seismic tremors, but the most serious episode occurred in September, 1348, when a powerful earthquake caused the tower’s summit to fall to the ground. The building became uninhabitable and was abandoned. It was rebuilt in 1620. Other collapses led to the construction of reinforcing buttresses at the end of the seventeenth century. The tower had three superimposed structures, becoming concave and developing in the upper reaches into a ‘telescopic’ shape. With an irregular quadrilateral plan, it was supported by a high sloping base with masonry in alternating strips of flint and marble flakes (the west side, entirely restored, has bands in inverse order). Further up, the body of the tower, in exposed brick, is reinforced by the seventeenth century buttresses, now without their arched crowns. The numerous open windows on the sides are of recent construction for residences within the structure.
poi - location - address - value: 00153 Lazio Roma  Largo Corrado Ricci largo

poi - description - value: The theatre was built on land owned by the Brancaccio princes and was inaugurated in 1916 with the name of the Teatro Morgana. Its construction followed a few years after the completion in the same block of the palace of the aristocratic family, the last palace of the nobility to be built in the city, whose name soon eclipsed the theatre's original one. Starting in the nineteenth thirties, as cinema spread, the premises were used as a projection theatre, which continued until 1978 when it once again became a theatre. Due to its location within the block (at the corner of Via Merulana and Via Mecenate), the exterior prospect, restored several times in the course of the years, is in the form of a semicircle and covered with a terrace that original housed part of the internal structure of the building.  In 1986, the theatre was acquired by the Ente Autonomo Teatro dell’Opera and used mostly for musical performances.
poi - location - address - value: 00185 Lazio Roma 244 Via Merulana Via

poi - description - value: On the reclamation of the Pantani, or Quagmires, as the marshy area at the rear of the Imperial Forums came to be known, and the construction of the sixteenth century Quartiere Alessandrino, Via Bonella became one of the main roads through the area.  Opened under the papacy of Pio V (Antonio Michele Ghislieri, 1566-1572) by Cardinal Camerlengo Michele Bonelli, the Pope’s nephew, it was built on around three metres of infill used in the reclamation of the area.   The new road, at right angles with the Via Alessandrina, was built over the route of an extension to the modern day Via della Madonna dei Monti, where butchers shops had given the area the name of Fundicus macellorum de Arcanohe.  Via Bonella, which no longer exists, began at the Arch of Septimius Severus, passed to the side of the church of Sant'Adriano, the ancient Curia of the Senate, and reached the Arco dei Pantani near the Forum of Augustus, where Via Baccina began.  A small stretch at the side of the Curia is all that now remains of Via Bonella, crossed by the modern day Via dei Fori Imperiali.  Among the buildings erected along it was the church of Santa Maria in Macello Martyrum, granted in 1517 to the University of Weavers and named Sant’Agata dei Tessitori. The entrance to the historical seat (later demolished) of the Academy of San Luca, later moved to Palazzo Carpegna, once overlooked Via Bonella.Along the road, shops and inns were opened which characterised the area in the nineteenth century. Around the middle of the century, there were at least five: at No. 5, the Osteria della Villetta, at No. 11, that of the Mascherone, at No.31, the Sign of the Corona (known at least since the XVII secolo), the Caffè del Foro di Traiano at No.35 and the Osteria della Vetrina at No. 61. Via Bonella, which crossed the southern side of the monumental complex of the Imperial Forums, was demolished with the rest of the Alessandrino district in 1932 and replaced with a footbridge.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via Bonella via

poi - description - value: La chiesa di Santa Maria in 'Macello Martyrum', distrutta nel 1931 per la costruzione di via dell’Impero, era collocata, rispetto alla topografia attuale, lungo la corsia di destra di via dei Fori Imperiali nel tratto in cui si affianca all’asse di via Alessandrina. Nel XII secolo l’edificio era dedicato a San Marco Evangelista le cui spoglie erano state qui traslate. La denominazione in  'Macello Martyrum' compare solo nella piena età medievale per la presenza di un mercato, il Macellum Torrechianum, al quale la devozione popolare collegava il ricordo del martirio dei primi cristiani. Nel XVI secolo la chiesa passò alla confraternita dei tessitori che la dedicarono alla loro protettrice Sant’Agata. Nel XVIII secolo divenne proprietà dei frati detti Scalzetti assumendo la denominazione di Santa Maria degli Angeli. La chiesa, ben delineata nella pianta del Nolli e nelle stampe di Vasi, dove compare anche il vicino portico del Foro di Nerva, presentava una semplice facciata decorata da paraste e l’interno ad una sola navata con altari laterali decorati con statue lignee e affreschi.
poi - location - address - value: 00187 Lazio Roma  Via Alessandrina via

poi - description - value: The photograph, taken in 1932, documents the church of Santa Maria degli Angeli erected over the medieval Santa Maria in Macello Martyrum in the area of the ancient Forum of Nerva. Tradition has it that the bodies of Christian martyrs killed in the nearby Forum were thrown into the well inside the church. From 1517, the church was dedicated to Sant’Agata, patron saint of weavers. The sacred building stood at the junction between Via della Croce Bianca and Via Alessandrina. The area was completely modified by the construction of the modern day Via dei Fori Imperiali and by the excavations carried out at the eastern edge of the Forum of Nerva between 1931 and 1932 which isolated part of the complex from the Roman era, demolishing the later structures built on and around it. This was the fate of the little church, knocked down in September, 1932, although the Renaissance façade with two lunettes decorated with the heads of cherubim was preserved.
poi - label - term: Foro di Traiano. Chiesa di Santa Maria in Macello Martyrum in via Alessandrina
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma  Via dei Fori Imperiali Via

poi - description - value: Nell’ambito dei lavori per la costruzione del Vittoriano iniziati nel 1885, e completati con l’inaugurazione del 1911, fu dato un nuovo assetto alle pendici del Campidoglio, abbattendo a più riprese gli edifici situati a nord della scalinata dell’Aracoeli, fino all’attuale piazza Venezia. La fisionomia dell’area fu ulteriormente modificata a causa delle demolizioni effettuate nei lavori per la via del Mare (oggi via del teatro di Marcello), negli anni Trenta del Novecento. In questa occasione la chiesa di Santa Rita, a sinistra nella fotografia, sorta sull’antica San Biagio de Mercatello, fu smontata nel 1928 per essere rimontata in via Montanara nel 1940.La fotografia, eseguita intorno al 1888, prima della realizzazione del Vittoriano, mostra la scalinata dell’Aracoeli con la cancellata di ferro e il vicolo della Pedacchia, non più esistente.  A sinistra tra gli edifici poi demoliti, la chiesa di Santa Rita da Cascia, qui ripresa nella sua originaria collocazione.
poi - label - term: Le pendici del Campidoglio prima delle demolizioni per il Vittoriano
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via del Teatro di Marcello Via

poi - description - value: The prototype for suburban Renaissance villas in Rome, it was designed for the rich and powerful banker Agostino Chigi by Baldassarre Peruzzi around 1508. Violently plundered by the Lanzichenecchi during the sack of Rome in 1527, it was acquired at the end of the century by the Farnese, adopting the name of Farnesina in order to distinguish it from the grand city palace on the opposite bank, to which it was intended to be connected by a bridge according to a design by Michelangelo, never carried out.  A little slipway allowed communication between the two properties.  The building, integrated into the surrounding countryside, had an innovative plan with a central block opening towards the formal garden, with a five arched loggia bordered by two protruding sections, recalling Tuscan architectural models.  The rear façade, facing the Tiber, has two orders of windows with architraves accompanied by pilasters. The building is surmounted by a large cornice with corbels and a frieze of cherubs and candelabras between festoons of fruit and flowers. The façade was originally decorated according to the fashion of the early years of the sixteenth century. The design of the separate pavilion, perhaps used as stables, is attributed to Raphael. Between the palace and the Tiber stood the Viridarium, bathed by the river, perhaps designed by Raphael, which was destroyed with part of the gardens in 1884 in order to build the Lungotevere. The gardens of the Renaissance villa sloped downwards with steep banks, pavilions, a grotto with fish pond and culminated with a loggia on the river, used as an exedra (a dining room). At the end of one of the sumptuous banquets in 1518, it is said the gold dishes were thrown into the river (presumably recovered later from hidden nets). The greatest artists of the Renaissance collaborated on the splendid decoration of the interiors, such as Raphael, Giulio Romano, Sebastiano del Piombo, Baldassarre Peruzzi and Sodoma. A complex iconographic scheme inspired by the classics is combined with scenographic effects of illusionistic views of landscapes and Roman architecture.  The villa passed to the Bourbons in 1704 and housed the Academy of Naples founded by Carlo III. Today it is the home of the Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei.In the nineteenth century works on the Lungotevere, a Roman villa of a person of high rank was brought to light with sophisticated decoration in frescos dating from around 20 A.D., preserved at the Museum of Palazzo Massimo alle Terme.
poi - location - address - value: 00165 Lazio Roma 230 Via della Lungara Via

poi - description - value: Probably by Girolamo Rainaldi, commissioned by Cardinal Odoardo Farnese, the fountain was completed in 1626  following the construction of the Acqua Paola in 1612. In the seventeenth century, the Fontana del Mascherone, which now stands against a late nineteenth century wall in Via Giulia, was located in the square behind Palazzo Farnese which, in the middle of the seventeenth century, housed an open air theatre.  The fountain reused a rectangular granite basin from ancient baths, attached to a white marble façade with lateral scrolls and a central mask, from which the fountain took its name. The water, gushing from the mouth of the mask, is collected first by a small, semicircular basin in the shape of a conch from which it falls into the main basin. The Farnese lily, originally in travertine, stands at the top.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via Giulia Via

poi - description - value: L’elegante fontana delle Tartarughe, in origine destinata a Piazza Giudia, fu realizzata da Giacomo della Porta tra il 1581 e il 1584 su pressione di Muzio Mattei nella piazza del palazzo di famiglia. Il consueto schema, già più volte utilizzato dall’architetto, venne in questo caso abbandonato a favore di una composizione nella quale l’elemento scultoreo era prevalente, probabilmente a causa anche dell’influenza dello scultore Taddeo Landini che vi collaborò. Modello di riferimento fu forse la fontana del Nettuno a Firenze, opera di Bartolomeo Ammannati (1563-75)  con statue bronzee di satiri e fauni.  Elemento centrale nella fontana del Della Porta diventano così i quattro efebi di bronzo col braccio sollevato disposti con i delfini a sovrastare le raffinate vasche di marmo di portasanta in forma di conchiglia. Sul bordo del catino un restauro voluto da papa Alessandro VII (Fabio Chigi 1655-1667) nel 1658, ampliò la piscina quadrangolare esterna e aggiunse, forse ad opera di Gian Lorenzo Bernini, le quattro tartarughe di bronzo in atto di saltare nel bacino.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Piazza Mattei Piazza

poi - description - value: In the High Middle Ages, the restricted area of the Forum of Nerva, also known in antiquity as the Transitorio because it lay along the route connecting the Subura and the Roman Forum, housed within its powerful perimeter walls a residential district crossed by a longitudinal road axis that retraced the ancient route. A number of houses constructed in the course of the IX century faced onto the cobbled road. Two of these domus were brought to light by recent excavations conducted in the area. They were two-story structures, constructed with materials expropriated from existing buildings, flanked by courtyards for animals and equipped with a well for water. In the course of the IX century, a porch was added to the facade of one of the houses, built with large blocks of tuff. The structure, with four round arches on the front facing the road and an arch on each side, is still perfectly preserved. After the buildings of the High Middle Ages were abandoned, they were encompassed in the foundations of a later building, itself demolished in the nineteen thirties to construct the Via dell’Impero.A similar structure to the earlier ones, it was used as the residence of the wealthiest family in Rome in the High Middle Ages. The interior of the portico in front of the basilica Emilia has been preserved. The residence, constructed with blocks of reused material, was discovered in the course of the XIX century. The remains of the upper floor, in brick, were preserved. Access was gained by an exterior stairway and, on the front elevation, an arched door has been preserved.
poi - label - term: Resti di case altomedioevali del Foro Transitorio
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via Alessandrina, Via dei  Fori Imperiali via

poi - description - value: In piazza San Pietro in Vincoli è visibile una torre medievale, forse eretta nel XII secolo, poi annessa alla seicentesca chiesa di San Francesco di Paola. Il monumento, tradizionalmente detto torre dei Borgia, appartenne in origine ai Cesarini e da ultimo ai Margani, dei quali rimane uno stemma frammentario murato nella cortina. La torre, a base quadrata, presenta una cortina di laterizi a vista, con feritoie su uno dei fianchi, al di sopra delle quali è collocato lo stemma. In alto si aprono due finestre rettangolari, con mostra in travertino. Alla sommità, nel XV-XVI secolo, venne aggiunto un coronamento in beccatelli di travertino a sostegno di una loggetta. Nel 1632 la zona prossima alla torre fu interessata dalla costruzione della chiesa e del convento di San Francesco di Paola, probabilmente insediatisi nell'area dove sorgeva un edificio residenziale annesso alla torre stessa. Le strutture di questa vennero alterate per trasformarla in campanile, aggiungendo alla sommità della torre una cella campanaria formata da quattro archetti, sostenuti da piedritti, tra i quali sono sospese le campane.
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma 2 Piazza di San Pietro in Vincoli piazza

poi - description - value: Tra i pionieri della fotografia a Roma, Pompeo Molins riprende nel 1868 la cinquecentesca fontana, opera di Giacomo della Porta e dello scultore Taddeo Landini.  L’elegante fontana, cui furono aggiunte nel  1658 le tartarughe sul bordo del catino superiore che le diedero il nome, è collocata nella piazza Mattei  in posizione assiale rispetto al centro della facciata di uno dei palazzi della potente famiglia romana, che fa da quinta alla fontana. Nella consueta raffinata composizione dell’immagine, Pompeo Molins accosta alla rappresentazione tradizionale del monumento una serie di personaggi,  apparentemente colti come in un’istantanea, in realtà modelli in posa utilizzati per animare la scena. Lo sfondo della fotografia è occupato dalla facciata cinquecentesca del palazzo di Giacomo Mattei, che unificò due edifici preesistenti, quello a destra  (fuori dal campo visivo) della fine del Quattrocento, noto come casa di Domenico Mattei, e quello  a sinistra attribuito a Nanni di Baccio Bigio. La facciata era decorta conaffreschi monocromi della metà del Cinquecento del pittore manierista Taddeo Zuccari con le storie di Furio Camillo.
poi - label - term: Fontana delle Tartarughe a piazza Mattei

poi - description - value: Piazza Mattei lies between Via dei Falegnami and Via dei Funari. It takes its name from Giacomo Mattei’s palace, the most ancient in the complex of residences possessed by the family in the area. The palace is composed of two buildings, the oldest dating from the end of the fifteenth century which was restored in the middle of the sixteenth century, uniting its façade with the other. To the left at the opposite side of the square, at the corner with Via della Reginella, stands the palace of the Costaguti family (who still own it), originally from Rapallo but present in Rome since the XVI century. Important paintings are preserved in the building (Guercino, Domenichino and Zuccari) along with furnishings from the period. The most noteworthy element of the square is the Fontana delle Tartarughe, supplied by the Acqua Vergine. It was designed by Giacomo Della Porta and built by Taddeo Landini between 1581 and 1584.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Piazza Mattei Piazza

poi - description - value: The Argiletum was the ancient road linking the Roman Forum with the heavily populated quarter of the Subura, partially followed today by the present Via della Madonna dei Monti. According to some scholars, the term defined an entire quarter that grew up starting from the Republic era on the valley to the northeast of the Roman Forum.  The Argiletum was divided in two parts: to the southeast, between Via dell’Argileto and the Velian hill, the quarter may have been highly commercial in nature, with the presence of numerous markets from the III B.C.; the northwestern sector, between the street and the saddle joining the Quirinal and the Capitoline, was occupied by residential buildings, partially demolished to make way for the Forums of Caesar and Augustus (between 46 B.C. and 2 B.C.).  In the I century with the installation of the Templum Pacis and the Forum of Nerva, the most ancient quarter entirely disappeared.  In the high Middle Ages, a core of residences developed around the area of the Forum of Nerva and to control the road the Torre dei Conti was built, one of the highest in the city. In the XVI century, the Alessandrino Quarter was constructed in the area, in large part demolished in the nineteen thirties.
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma  Via della Madonna dei Monti via

poi - description - value: In the Roman era, the eastern sector of the Esquiline hill featured a series of horti (monumental parks with grand residences). The Horti Liciniani, owned by Emperor Gallienus (253-268 A.D.), covered an area between the Aurelian Walls and the Via Labicana (between the modern day Stazione Termini and Via di Porta Maggiore). It has been possible to identify with certainty the position of the imperial palace thanks to a number of sources from the high Middle Ages which locate it close to the tomb and church of S. Bibiana. During the Constantine era, the Horti Liciniani were incorporated in the imperial residence of the Sessorium, where Sant’Elena, mother of the emperor Constantine, lived.  Belonging to the architecture of this period were the structures of the so-called Temple of Minerva Medica, interpreted as the nymphaeum of the palace, probably part of a system of Baths. Numerous architectural elements, slabs of marble and statues have been recovered in the area: of particular importance is a mosaic depicting a hunting scene, rediscovered at the beginning of the twentieth century near the church of Santa Bibiana during the works for the construction of the railway, which can be seen today at the Capitoline Museums – Montemartini Station.
poi - location - address - value: 00185 Lazio Roma  Via G. Giolitti  Via

poi - description - value: La chiesa, realizzata alla metà del IV secolo sulle strutture di una grande domus e intitolata agli Apostoli Pietro e Paolo, venne ricostruita nella prima metà del V secolo ad opera dell’imperatrice Eudossia (moglie dell'imperatore Valentiniano III) che volle qui conservare le catene di San Pietro (da cui la denominazione ad vincula sancti Petri Apostoli). Giulio II (Giuliano Della Rovere,1503-13), ristrutturò l’edificio in forme rinascimentali. Nello stesso periodo furono completatati il convento e il chiostro opera di Giuliano da Sangallo. La facciata è articolata in due corpi di differenti epoche: il porticato a cinque arcate poggianti su pilastri ottagonali in travertino dell’impianto rinascimentale e la sopraelevazione di epoca successiva. L’interno è a tre navate con colonne e capitelli dorici pertinenti alla chiesa di V secolo. L’opera più rilevante è costituita dalla Cappella Della Rovere col Mausoleo di Giulio II, opera di Michelangelo, dominata dalla celebre statua del Mosè. La zona presbiteriale ospita una confessio in cui è inserita la teca-reliquario delle sacre catene.Autori: Giuliano Giamberti detto da Sangallo (1445-1516), Buonarroti Michelangelo (1475-1564)
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma 4/a Piazza San Pietro in Vincoli piazza

poi - description - value: Liberamente tratto dal romanzo Ragazzi di vita di Pier Paolo Pasolini, La notte brava narra le vicende di un gruppo di borgatari romani, che oggi chiameremmo bulli, capitanati da Scintillone e Ruggeretto, e di alcune prostitute, che bazzicano tutti nella zona di Caracalla. E' da queste parti che viene ambientata la scena in cui i quattro giovani dapprima rimangono coinvolti in una rissa in un locale, poi importunano Nicoletta, una delle prostitute del loro giro, ed infine donano il sangue in un centro mobile situato in Piazza S. Pietro in Vincoli. In un fotogramma della sequenza, la macchina su cui viaggiano i ragazzi si ferma davanti alla chiesa di S. Pietro in Vincoli, di cui si notano quattro delle arcate del portico.
poi - label - term: San Pietro in Vincoli - La notte brava

poi - description - value: Originariamente ospitato nel palazzo in via dei Banchi Vecchi, il Monte di Pietà istituito nel 1539 da Paolo III (Alessandro Farnese 1534-1549), fu spostato da Sisto V (Felice Peretti 1585-1590) in via dei Coronari e poi nel 1603 da Clemente VIII (Ippolito Aldobrandini 1592-1605) nella sede definitiva di piazza Monte di Pietà.  Il palazzo era stato progettato nella seconda metà del Cinquecento come residenza del cardinale Prospero Santacroce da Ottavio Mascarino. I lavori di adattamento dell’edifico, ai quali collaborò il giovane Francesco Borromini,  furono affidati a Carlo Maderno che prolungò la struttura verso destra. Sulla facciata principale, opera del Mascarino, tra i due portali architravati il Maderno aggiunse al centro una fontana, sormontata da un’edicola con una Pietà e gli stemmi di Paolo III (fondatore dell’istituzione), di Clemente VIII (che vi aveva trasferito la sede), del nipote cardinale Pietro Aldobrandini e del Popolo Romano.  Nel cortile interno il Maderno fece collocare una fontana centrale, alimentata dall’acqua Paola.Tra il 1735 e il 1740 fu realizzata la facciata posteriore da Nicola Salvi, poi sopraelevata nel XIX secolo.Autori: Mascarino Ottavio (1536-1606), Maderno Carlo (1556-1629), Borromini Francesco (1599-1667), Salvi Nicola (1697-1751)
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma 32 Piazza Monte di Pietà via

poi - description - value: Santa Caterina dei Funari è menzionata per la prima volta in un documento del 1192 come Sancta Maria dominae Rosae e Sancta Maria in castro aureo. La prima denominazione indica la fondatrice della chiesa, sorta con l'annesso monastero intorno al IX secolo sui resti della Crypta Balbi, all'interno del Castrum Aureum (da cui deriva la seconda denominazione). L'attuale appellativo si riferisce ai fabbricanti di funi che praticavano la loro arte nel quartiere. Tra la fine del XII e l'inizio del XIII secolo l'edificio venne ampliato considerevolmente, ma le forme attuali derivano dal rifacimento attuato tra 1560 e 1564 su iniziativa di Ignazio di Loyola, che aveva costituito nel monastero una casa per ragazze povere. Il progetto fu affidato a Guidetto Guidetti, architetto allievo di Michelangelo. La facciata si ispira a modelli tardorinascimentali: si compone di due ordini architettonici sovrapposti con paraste dai capitelli corinzi che delimitano riquadri con nicchie. Tra questi si stende una fascia adorna di festoni con gli emblemi della ruota, della rosa, delle palme; completano il prospetto le volute ed il timpano superiore. I resti di una torre del XV secolo furono impiegati per innalzarvi il piccolo campanile. L'interno è a navata unica coperta a volta, con tre cappelle per lato, ed ospita opere di alcuni tra i più insigni artisti del manierismo romano: Incoronazione di Maria di Annibale Carracci, Deposizione di Girolamo Muziano, Assunzione di Scipione Pulzone, Storie di Santa Caterina di Federico Zuccari, Martirio di Santa Caterina e Gloria della Santa di Livio Agresti, Storie di San Giovanni di Marcello Venusti.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via dei Funari via

poi - description - value: In 54 B.C., Gaius Julius Caesar arranged for a new forum complex to be designed behind the Roman Forum, for the construction of which major excavations were undertaken of the slopes of the Capitoline and the Quirinal hills. At the time of the inauguration of the new Forum Iulium in 46 B.C., the works were still incomplete and were later finished by Augustus. The latter was also responsible for the renovation of the Curia and the series of tabernae, perhaps with the function of public offices, incorporated in the western portico. The rectangular square was flanked on three sides by porticos with two aisles ending at the north in a semicircular apse. Also on the north side, standing against the excavated slopes of the Capitoline, was the temple consecrated to Venus Genetrix. Raised on a high podium, the building was surrounded on three sides by a Corinthian-style colonnade. In front of the temple there were two fountains and, at the centre of the square, the bronze equestrian statue of Caesar. The Forum was restored under Domitian after the fire of 64 A.D., and again by Trajan following new excavations for the construction of his own forum. On this occasion, the temple of Venus Genetrix was rebuilt, newly inaugurated in 113 A.D.. The columns in Lunense marble (three columns raised following the excavations of the thirties can be seen) bore rich trabeation adorned with acanthus scrolls. The decoration of the external walls was embellished in the spaces between the pilasters with sculptured panels bearing cherubs, also present in other parts of the architectural decoration. Trajan is also credited with a building divided by pillars in two aisles, known by the sources as Basilica Argentaria, and a large semicircular latrine. New restoration works were undertaken under Diocletian as a result of the fire of 283. A.D.. After the area was abandoned and stripped of the square’s travertine paving slabs, in the high Middle Ages at the beginning of the IX century the Forum was used for agricultural purposes with the planting of a vineyard and an orchard.  At the beginning of the X century, a settlement sprang up with dwellings along a transversal roadway. The swampy nature of the area led to its general decline and it was abandoned in the course of the XI century.
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma  Via dei Fori Imperiali Via

poi - description - value: Created at the wishes of Cardinal Girolamo Capodiferro between 1548 and 1550, the design of the palace is attributed to the architect Bartolomeo Baronino, who worked on the nearby building of Palazzo Farnese. The façade repeats the layout of high ashlar base, formerly used on the Palazzo Baldassini and on that of Angelo Massimo. However, the middle band, the work of Giulio Mazzoni (1525-1618), like the rich ornamentation of the inner courtyard, displays the Mannerist style in the decorative elements, housing a series of niches with statues of illustrious men from the history of Rome and tondi with the emblem of Cardinal Capodiferro, connected by festoons and caryatids.   Above the arches of the inner courtyard, the friezes and twelve niches with Olympic divinities allude to the ascent of the soul in the Neoplatonic conception and recall the humanist culture of the cardinal and his desire to bridge the pagan and Christian worlds.On the first floor is a wealth of fresco decoration, inspired by themes from the Classical world, the work of Giulio Mazzoni and his workshop. The famous Galleria degli Stucchi was modelled on the one at Fountainbleau of Francis I of France.The palace was acquired in 1632 by Cardinal Bernardino Spada, apostolic nuncio in France, who was responsible for the renovations in the seventeenth century, the work of Francesco Borromini, including the Galleria Prospettica (1652-1653), constructed in collaboration with his father, the mathematician, Giovanni Maria da Bitonto. The passage of just nine metres, designed to evoke wonder, an essential component of Baroque art, creates the visual effect of a length of thirty six metres through a false perspective created by the gradual narrowing of the walls, the ceiling and the floor.  Today, the palace houses the Council of State and the Galleria Spada.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma 3 Piazza Capodiferro Via

poi - description - value: The edifice was constructed by Carlo Maderno beginning in 1598 on the commission of Asdrubale Mattei, Marquis of Monte Giove, who had married Costanza Gonzaga. By the second half of the fifteenth century, the interests of the Mattei family were already concentrated in the Rione Sant’Angelo in the large block erected near the remains of the ancient theatre of Balbus, where the fortified settlement known as Castrum Aureum was developed in the IX century.  The palace was the last of the family’s buildings which formed the Isola dei Mattei.  From the exterior, it appeared to be a closed building in late sixteenth century style following the traditional model with the main courtyard separated from the rear garden by an arcade on a single level. In fact, the architecture reveals a more open layout which suggests the complex should be appreciated in its individual parts, with the contrast between the simplicity of the exterior and the richness of the internal courtyard with reliefs and antique statues.The palace has two entrances and two prospects, the main one facing towards the church of Santa Caterina dei Funari, the other on Via dei Funari. The two entrances offer similar perspectives but with different development.  One opens on the thoroughfare of Via dei Funari framed by the arcade of the inner courtyard that displayed one of the major collections of ancient marble in the city. The other opens on Via Caetani from the landing of the large, four ramp stairway, flanked by statues. The three-story palace is surmounted by a cornice decorated with the heraldic motifs of the Mattei and the Gonzaga and by a rooftop loggia with arcade, set on the medieval tower known as Turris Salitulae.Inside are paintings with themes from the Old Testament by the major painters active in Rome in the early seventeenth century: Francesco Albani, Lanfranco, Pomarancio and Pietro da Cortona.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma 32 Via Caetani Via

poi - description - value: I resti di un’insula (edificio abitativo a più piani, al cui interno si distinguevano più unità immobiliari) visibili ai piedi della scalinata dell'Ara Coeli tra questa ed il Vittoriano, furono scoperti alle pendici orientali del Campidoglio durante i lavori di isolamento del colle (1930-1942). Dell’edificio restano cinque piani, tutti ben conservati tranne l'ultimo, oltre ad un mezzanino. Il piano terra  era occupato da botteghe aperte su un cortile con portico a pilastri. Le taberne comunicavano con un mezzanino dotato in origine di una pavimentazione lignea, spesso destinato all’alloggio del personale o utilizzato come vano magazzino. I piani superiori erano invece destinati agli appartamenti in affitto con ambienti illuminati da finestre che prendono luce dalla strada. Al secondo piano sono presenti anche le tracce di una balconata lignea poggiante su mensole di travertino. L’insula è datata sulla base delle murature laterizie al II d.C. Essa costituisce un tipico esempio di edilizia intensiva a destinazione abitativa presente a Roma e in altre città, come Ostia, nella piena età imperiale. In epoca medievale sul un lato dell’insula  si appoggiò la costruzione della chiesetta di San  Biagio del Mercato, alla quale appartengono il campanile romanico e i resti di un arcosolio decorato con un affresco trecentesco risparmiati dalle demolizione  degli anni Trenta. Venne invece distrutta, per essere ricostruita vicino al Teatro di Marcello, la settecentesca chiesa di San Rita, che a sua volta aveva inglobato la chiesetta romanica.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Piazza dell’Ara Coeli piazza

poi - description - value: In 1612, on the initiative of the Barnabiti, a church dedicated to San Carlo Borromeo was constructed on the site of the existing church of San Biagio dell’Anello with the consent of Paolo V (Camillo Borghese, 1605-1621). The church was completed in 1646, thanks also to the generous bequest of the constable, Filippo Colonna.The façade of Giovanni Battista Soria of 1636-1638, in typical Baroque style, is in two superimposed orders, with large arched windows and a marble balustrade at the centre of the upper register. The cupola, one of the largest in Rome, was often depicted in views of the city, as was that of Sant’Andrea della Valle.  The interior in the shape of an elongated Greek cross preserves the Baroque pictorial decoration of the plumes of the cupola by Domenichino and the apse by Giovanni Lanfranco, in addition to the canvass by Pietro da Cortona in 1667 at the high altar, depicting San Carlo Borromeo.In 1722, the church was consecrated by Cardinal Lorenzo Corsini, later Pope with the name of Clemente XII (1730-40).Beneath the adjacent convent, remains of a building from the Imperial Roman era, with a nymphanaeum, date from the III century A.D..  In 1848-49, the bodies of two of Garibaldi’s soldiers were temporarily buried there before being moved to the Janiculum.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma 117 Piazza Benedetto Cairoli piazza

poi - description - value: Via Florea or Florida was the name by which the route is known, only in part coinciding with the Via Peregrinorum, which ran from Campo de’ Fiori (Campus Florae) to the area of the modern day church of San Carolo ai Catinari along the path of the present Via dei Giubbonari. It then forked, on one side, towards Piazza Mattei, Piazza Margana and Piazza San Marco, then continued to San Giovanni in Laterano and, on the other, through the Portico d’Ottavia and Sant’Angelo in Pescheria and then onto Piazza Montanara in the direction of San Paolo fuori le mura. The route, formed of several segments retracing various medieval itineraries, was reorganised under Sisto IV (Francesco della Rovere, 1471-1484), as recorded on a plaque that can be seen today in Via dei Balestrari of 1483. The works under the Pope were carried out as part of an overall improvement of the road network to make the transit of pilgrims safer and easier. Roads were widened through the elimination of balconies, the closure of porticos and the demolition of protruding medieval buildings.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Piazza Margana Via

poi - description - value: Piazza Margana, in the Sant’ Angelo district, houses a tower of modest size, Tor Margana, named after its owners in medieval times. The Margani were a family of the minor nobility of the Roman aristocracy, rich merchants who also occupied public posts in the Capitoline and who, at the apex of their economic power, controlled a large part of the block where they lived from the XIII century until they died out in XVII. The tower, believed to date from the thirteenth century, has recently been the subject of new research that clarified its origins and its relationship with the adjacent structures, buildings constructed from the end of the XIII century to the end of the XVI century, which together form the Palazzo dei Margani. The tower dates from the first decades of the XV century and was the culminating element of a portico of six columns dominated by a three arched loggia that faces onto a courtyard where more recent buildings now stand. The square tower has brick walls with mortar beds framing the brick. An architrave cornice on corbels is a feature of the northeastern facade.  At the base on this side, there was an arch, now sealed up, resting on an expropriated column of the XII-XIII century with Ionic capital and marble base. The side overlooking the square is embellished with false ashlar plasterwork from the first half of the XV century. The summit of the tower is adorned with a loggia. Two marble paterae are fixed to the masonry depicting an eagle with wings spread, an allusion to the Margani coat-of-arms.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma 40a Piazza Margana piazza

poi - description - value: In the medieval era, the area between the Temple of Peace and the Forum of Augustus had become marshy again, as it was when the city was founded, due to the lack of an adequate system of draining the waters following the collapse of the drainage system of the Roman era, to the point the area was known as the Pantani or Quagmires (for example, the church of Sant’Urbano ai Pantani). Work to upgrade and develop the area only took place in the late XVI century on the orders of Cardinal Michele Bonelli, nephew of Pio V (Antonio Ghislieri, 1585-90), called Cardinal Alessandrino because of his birthplace (Bosco Marengo in the province of Alessandria). Via Alessandrina was the main road of the new district in which modest houses and the palaces of nobility were built (for example, the small palace of Flaminio Ponzio and the so-called palace of Sisto IV, or the Ghislieri), as well as artisan workshops and businesses, including the tavern inside the “Colonnacce” portrayed in numerous views. Via Alessandrina was opened on an extension of Via di Santa Eufemia, along the route that joined the church of Santa Maria in Campo Carleo, the tower of the Conti and the Basilica di Massenzio, continuing to the Colosseum. In a study of the area, Antonio da Sangollo the Younger (1484-1546) had already marked out the layout of what would later be Via Alessandrina as a straight connection between Santa Maria in Campo Carleo and Torre dei Conti, but the project was not carried out; in 1547, however, the stretch between the Torre dei Conti and the Colosseum was straightened and widened.At the beginning of the twentieth century, the position of the road in the area of the Forums of the Roman era and the desire to connect the new monumental complex of the Vittoriano with the Colosseum led to the demolition of the entire district and its centuries old stratification under a variation to the development plan. The works were completed in only a year in 1931 and resulted in the long straight route of Via dell'Impero (Via dei Fori Imperiali). Today, all that remains of Via Alessandrina is a long stretch of paved road and an overhead footbridge, from which the Forums of Augustus and Nerva can be admired.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via Alessandrina via

poi - description - value: Aperta nell’ultimo ventennio dell’Ottocento nell’ambito delle trasformazioni urbanistiche della Roma capitale, la nuova arteria di via Arenula portò ad un riassetto complessivo dell’area tra il Tevere e l’attuale largo di torre Argentina, tagliando il reticolo della viabilità di origine medievale e demolendo edifici storici e chiese. Tra queste ultime furono abbattute Santa Maria de’ Calderari, San Bartolomeo de’ Vaccinari, costruita sopra l’antica Santo Stefano de Arenula, Sant’Anna dei Falegnami e Sant’ Elena dei Credenzieri, che sorgeva sul luogo della più antica San Niccolò de Mellinis. La fotografia, databile intorno al 1880, mostra l’area tra l’attuale via Arenula e l’incrocio con via Florida, in direzione sud, nell’assetto precedente le demolizioni: sulla piccola piazza di Sant’Elena dei Credenzieri si apre la facciata della chiesa, ora non più esistente.
poi - label - term: Piazza Sant’Elena prima delle demolizioni per via Arenula
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via Arenula Via

poi - description - value: Piazza Vittorio, named for Vittorio Emanuele II, is the largest square in Rome at 316 x 174 metres. Constructed between 1882 and 1887, it took as its model English squares, rectangular with a central garden. Monumental residential buildings ring the square that are furnished with large porticos on the model of those in Turin. In order to construct the square, Piazza Guglielmo Pepe and the seventeenth century Villa di Massimiliano Palombara, a member of the Order of Rosacroce, was demolished but the so-called Porta Alchemica was dismantled and relocated around 1890 in the garden area alongside two identical statues from the temple of Serapis. The name of the gate and the aura of mystery that surrounds it are linked to the use of the villa by the esoteric circles of alchemists and scientists in which even Queen Cristina of Sweden took part. The gate may have been a sort of symbolic, idealised threshold and bore an obscure formula which, according to legend, was also linked to the Pietra filosofale or Philosopher’s stone, which could change base metal into gold.  At the northwest corner of the square are the remains of the Nymphaeum of Alessandro Severo, built above the castellum of the Aqua Iulia, called the Trofei di Mario during the Renaissance. The garden, recently subject to careful restoration works, is decorated with a fountain, the work of Mario Rutelli, called the “mixed grill” by Romans due to the presence of numerous sea animals. In 1902, the city’s largest retail market was moved elsewhere which led to the gradual decline of the area, culminating in the demolition of one of the palaces with porticos. Today the market is held under cover near the former barracks of the Caserma Sani and Caserma Pepe and the entire zone was subject to urban redevelopment. At the corner of the square with Via Napoleon III stands the early Christian church of Sant’Eusebio with the convent annex.
poi - location - address - value: 00185 Lazio Roma  Piazza Vittorio Emanuele II Piazza

poi - description - value: The archeological complex, erected between 19 and 13 B.C. by the Proconsul of Africa, Lucius Cornelius Balbus, on his return from his victorious campaigns in Libya, occupied an area of Campus Martius between Via delle Botteghe Oscure, Piazza Paganica, Via dei Funari and Via dei Polacchi.  The remains of the façade in travertine of the spectator area are visible in the courtyard of Palazzo Mattei Paganica and the radial support walls can be seen in the cellars of the surrounding palaces. The structures of the Crypta that lay in front of the theatre are better preserved and more easily seen following recent excavations. The building was formed of a three-armed portico (an internal passageway of 10.65 metres) which marked out a large open space of more than 60 metres within which a monument stood (perhaps a temple to the god Vulcan). On the east side of the portico was a vast, semicircular exedra (later converted into a latrine) to which a hall dedicated to the worship of Mithras was connected.  Abandoned in the V century A.D., the complex was used for some time for urban waste. At the start of the VIII century, the beginning of a permanent settlement is documented (connected to the church of Santa Maria Domine Rose) which culminated in the IX century in the formation of the small fort of Castrum Aureum and, in the XVI century, in the construction of the palaces of the Mattei family. One of the premises of the National Museum of Rome is now housed in the area, devoted to the transformation of the city between late antiquity and the Middle Ages.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Via delle Botteghe Oscure via

poi - description - value: Tra i soggetti prediletti dai vedutisti dell’Ottocento i monumenti dell’antica Roma occuparono un posto di rilievo. A partire dalla metà del XIX secolo il nuovo mezzo della fotografia offrì nuove possibilità alla passione dell’antico. Tra i più famosi fotografi che operavano nella Roma degli ultimi decenni dell’Ottocento, Gustave Eugene Chauffourier riprende questo scorcio del Foro di Augusto nel 1871. Il soggetto della fotografia è il fornice di uno degli ingressi secondari del complesso, conosciuto dal medioevo con il nome di Arco dei Pantani, che alludeva agli allagamenti frequenti nella zona. A sinistra sono visibili le colonne con capitelli corinzi del tempio di Marte Ultore, costruito nel 42 a.C., che dominava il Foro di Augusto. L’immagine mostra il passaggio dell’arco ancora in uso. Nel 1926 gli scavi che interessarono i Fori imperiali abbassarono la quota del piano di calpestio nell’area adiacente al tempio di Marte Ultore, interrompendo la continuità con via Baccina, che si apriva oltre l’arco dei Pantani.
poi - label - term: Tempio di Marte Ultore e Arco dei Pantani
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma  Via Alessandrina Via

poi - description - value: Upon the extension of the Acqua Felice during the papacy of Sisto V (Felice Peretti, 1585-1590), the marble and travertine fountain in Piazza Aracoeli was commissioned and constructed in 1589 to the design of Giacomo della Porta. The fountain consisted of an elongated basin with four masks on the edges originally resting on two steps which mirrored its shape, eliminated in 1860 with the replacement of the lower basin with the current circular one.  On the upper circular basin, supported by a central element with masks and festoons and by a baluster, four cherubs pour water from little amphoras. The project of Pope Alessandro VII (Fabio Chigi, 1655-1667) to transfer the fountain to Piazza Santi Apostoli was abandoned and the pope’s intervention was limited to its restoration and the inclusion of the heraldic coat-of-arms of the Chigi on the baluster, alongside that of the Roman people.The demolitions for the urban redevelopment between the end of the XIX century and the early decades of the XX century for the construction of the Vittoriano first and then the opening of the Via del Mare, completely changed the urban context in which the sixteenth century fountain had been placed.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Piazza Aracoeli Piazza

poi - description - value: The Forum of Augustus, with the temple dedicated to Mars Ultor, was inaugurated in 2 A.D., thus keeping faith with the oath sworn on the eve of the battle of Filippi in 42.B.C. The Forum was separated from the populous district of the Subura by a substantial wall in blocks of peperino, or volcanic tuff.  Where the sides of the temple met the rear wall two entrances opened, embellished in 19 A.D. by arches dedicated to the Princes Drusus and Germanicus.  On the rear wall were two secondary entrances, one of which was known in the Middle Ages as Arco dei Pantani. The great rectangular, elongated square, paved in slabs of white Lunense marble, was dominated by the temple, flanked by two long porticos, behind which were two pairs of semicircles. The two southern semicircles, the smallest in size, were demolished with the construction of the Forums of Nerva and Trajan. A frontal stairway, with fountains at the edges and a central altar, gave access to the temple on a high podium. The cella or inner chamber at the rear wall was surrounded on three sides by a Lunense marble colonnade in Corinthian style. The last three columns on the southwest side, with a stretch of architrave, remain visible. Within the richly decorated cella, the apse at the rear contained the statues for the worship of Mars and Venus. To the west of the temple was the hall for worship of the imperial figure with the colossal statue to the Genius of Augustus. The porticos at the sides of Forum, with Corinthian columns in ancient yellow marble and precious flooring in multicoloured marble, were embellished by an attic decorated with female caryatid figures alternating with clipei, with the heads of Jupiter Ammon and other divinities. The porticos gave access to the decorated semicircles from a grand central niche with statuary groups of Enea and Romulus, flanked by two rows above of minor niches. The gallery of statutes depicting royal personages of the Giulia family and mythical figures from the story of Rome in the exedra and porticos expressed the ideological manifesto of Augustus, centred on the celebration of the new golden age inaugurated with advent of his principate. With the abandonment of the Forum in late antiquity, demolitions began of the architectural structures. At the beginning of the IX century on the site of the temple of Mars Ultor, a monastery was erected dedicated to San Basilio, forming part, from the beginning of the XIII century, of the property of the Knights of San Giovanni di Gerusalemme, the future Knights of Rhodes and finally of Malta, who made it the headquarters of their Roman priorate.  A church with a small apse located 6 metres above the floor of the Forum also dates from this period, bearing witness to the remarkable increase in levels that had obliterated the ancient vestiges of the monument. In the second half of the XVI century, the Alessandrino district rose up here, since demolished, built over Via Alessandrina.
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma  Via dei Fori Imperiali Via

poi - description - value: La chiesa fu eretta nel 1580 sul luogo del ritrovamento di una miracolosa immagine della Vergine con il Bambino tra i santi Stefano e Lorenzo. Il progetto per la costruzione del nuovo edificio in cui doveva essere custodita l’icona (risalente agli inizi del XV secolo) fu affidato a Giacomo Della Porta, il quale prese a modello sia per la facciata che per l’interno la Chiesa del Gesù da lui completata qualche anno prima. Il prospetto è articolato in due ordini di lesene con coronamento a timpano triangolare. L’ordine inferiore presenta lesene di tipo corinzio che ripartiscono la superficie in cinque settori. Al centro, il portale di ingresso è a edicola con timpano triangolare ed è fiancheggiato da nicchie. Nell’ordine superiore, caratterizzato da lesene di tipo composito, lo schema dei settori centrali sottostanti viene ripetuto nella composizione della grande finestra a edicola (ma con timpano arcuato) affiancata da nicchie, mentre alle estremità lo sviluppo ortogonale del prospetto è interrotto da volute laterali replicate in sequenza sui fianchi della costruzione. L’interno, a pianta centrale allungata con cappelle laterali, ha volta a botte e cupola emisferica all’incrocio del transetto. Nella volta, nell’abside e nelle cappelle si conservano affreschi della fine del XVI e degli inizi del XVII secolo. Della Porta Giacomo (1533-1602)
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma 41 Via della Madonna dei Monti Via

poi - description - value: This photograph, taken around 1888, documents the area that would be demolished to make way for the Vittoriano, corresponding to the junction between Via Giulio Romano and Via Macel de' Corvi. In the demolitions, the houses of famous artists like Michelangelo and Giulio Romano would be knocked down, among many others. The viewpoint is to the northeast of the western side of the Vittoriano, where Via Giulio Romano stood, known as Via della Pedacchio before 1870.The view of the photograph is similar to that reproduced in a watercolour by Ettore Roesler Franz in 1885. Alongside the sacred shrine at the corner, already deprived of its image of the Madonna, the brackets of a medieval building can be seen in the photograph that are identified as belonging to the house of Giulio Romano.  Before 1524, the artist had altered the façade of his residence, later lost following the roadworks in the quarter at the time of Paolo III (Alessandro Farnese, 1534-1549) when the Renaissance façade was incorporated in the structures erected along the new road.
poi - label - term: Via Giulio Romano, assetto prima delle demolizioni per il Vittoriano
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Piazza Venezia Piazza

poi - description - value: The building of the Vittoriano began in 1885 to the design of the architect Giuseppe Sacconi in order to celebrate Vittorio Emanuele II and, through him, the entire Risorgimento. The tender was announced in 1880, two years after the death of the first king of Italy. In order to build it, the entire area of the ancient square was altered and half of the Capitoline hill was sacrificed. The original design envisaged the use of Roman travertine but the monument was later completed in Botticino marble (from the district in the province in Brescia where the prime minister Giuseppe Zanardelli was born). In 1905, on Sacconi’s death, the direction of the project was assigned to Pio Piacentini, Gaetano Koch and Manfredo Manfredi. The monument was inaugurated in 1911, the fiftieth anniversary of the Unification of Italy, but the works were then still underway, especially on the decorative devices and the interior arrangement, and were only finished in 1935. Inspired, without much sense of proportion, by the classical repertoire (from the Pergamon Altar to the sanctuary of Palestrina, from the Parthenon to the Ara Pacis), it is formed of a terraced structure united by stairways and crowned by a high column portico terminating at the sides in two propylaeums in the form of small temples, surmounted by quadrigas, or four-horse chariots (Unità della Patria and Libertà dei Cittadini). At the top of the main stairway is the Altare della Patria: inside, the Unknown Soldier is entombed, the body of an unknown Italian soldier chosen from among those who fell during the First World War.  The imposing frieze is noteworthy at 80 metres in length, dominated by the figure of the goddess Roma, depicting the Trionfo del Lavoro and the Trionfo dell’Amor Patrio, above which stands the large bronze equestrian monument to Vittoria Emanuele II.
poi - location - address - value: 00186 Lazio Roma  Piazza Venezia piazza

poi - description - value: With the completion of the reclamation of the valley of the Roman Forum and the conversion of the slopes of the Palatine into the Horti Farnesiani gardens, Paolo III (Alessandro Farnese 1534-1549) continued with the project for the overall reorganisation of the Capitoline and the adjacent areas that was concluded with the archeological transformation of the square designed by Michelangelo. Paolo III wanted to build a summer residence with a tower on the Capitoline, between 1535 and 1539, connected to the Palazetto di Venezia, the papal residence, by a suspended corridor with covered arches, first in wood, then in stone, as part of the overall design of a grand papal residence stretching between San Marco and the Capitoline. The symbolic importance of the hill arose from the desire to underline the continuity between the power of Imperial Rome and the temporal power of the Pope. The tower, destroyed at the end of the nineteenth century in order to construct the monument to Vittorio Emanuele II, was part of a wider reorganisation of the northern side of the hill, entirely surrounded by the high wall extending from the slopes to the Capitoline square. Erected by the architect Jacopo Meleghino, the tower was isolated from the rest of the city and was located in line with the Corso so that, for those travelling along the most important road of the southern part of the city, it dominated the landscape.The structure, with a sloping quadrangular base, followed a fifteenth century model with a façade presenting a loggia with three arches arranged in two orders.  It was crowned by corbels enclosed by battlements. The tower, which recalled the shape of a medieval fortress, was intended to display papal authority, especially in its symbolic position near Palazzo Senatorio, the seat of power of the city authorities.
poi - location - address - value: 00187 Lazio Roma  Piazza Venezia Piazza

poi - description - value: La sistemazione urbanistica moderna nella zona degli antichi Fori Imperiali venne avviata nella seconda metà del XVI secolo dal cardinale Michele Bonelli, nipote di papa Pio V (Antonio Ghislieri 1566-1572), detto l'Alessandrino dalla sua zona di origine. La zona venne prima interessata da un’imponente opera di bonifica, a causa dell’impaludamento dopo l’intasamento della Cloaca Maxima, da cui l’area derivò il toponimo medievale “Li Pantani”. Sul nuovo piano di calpestio, pressoché simile all’attuale, venne intrapresa una lottizzazione dei terreni che proseguì fino agli inizi del XVII secolo. Sull’orientamento delle due nuove arterie stradali principali, la via Alessandrina e la Via Bonella, incrociatesi ad angolo retto presso il tempio di Marte Ultore, si allinearono le altre vie e il tessuto edilizio dell’area. I limiti del nuovo quartiere erano compresi tra le pendici del Campidoglio e della Velia, il muro della Suburra e il Foro Romano. Vi sorgevano case modeste, ma anche edifici di rilievo, come il palazzetto detto di Sisto IV (probabile palazzo dei Ghislieri), la chiesa di Santa Eufemia, la chiesa di Sant’ Urbano ai Pantani e annessi ospizi e conservatori, il palazzo attribuito a Flaminio Ponzio (poi ricostruito in piazza Campitelli). La topografia del quartiere rimase sostanzialmente immutata fino ai primi decenni del ‘900, quando fu progettata la costruzione dell’attuale via dei Fori Imperiali per la realizzazione della quale fu programmato lo sventramento sistematico dell’intero quartiere Alessandrino e il taglio di parte della collina della Velia.
poi - location - address - value: 00184 Lazio Roma  Via dei Fori Imperiali Via

poi - description - value: The church was founded by Silvestro I (314-335), probably on the site of an ancient building of the III century, made up of six rooms covered by cross vaults (perhaps a market or a warehouse). It is not clear whether this first structure was superimposed on the donation of the presbyter Equizius or whether the titulus Equitii was separate building, replaced in the VI century with a church dedicated to San Martino alone.  In the written sources of the period of Pope Adriano I (772-795), the existence of two separate buildings seems certain.
